Name: Written in My Own Heart's Blood: A Novel (Outlander)

ReviewList.Text: I LOVE this series.  I have recommended the Outlander series to many, many people.  I couldn't wait (and wait we all did) for Written in My Own Hearts' Blood.  I didn't like it.  I feel like it was so disconnected.  I didn't find myself caring about anything that was going on.  There are too many characters, too many story lines, not enough Jamie and Claire.  If I wanted a detailed description (and be detailed I mean droning on and on and on) of the Battle of Monmouth, I would pick up a history book.  This book barely wrapped up the lose ends from the last book and just made a million more.  We are introduced to a bunch of new story lines being started and then *poof* nothing.  The story threads just get dropped with no conclusion, no explanation, no satisfaction.  Why introduce these characters and scenarios and then have them go nowhere?  With 800 pages one would think something could get wrapped up.  I couldn't be more disappointed.  I waited 4 years for this book and I think Ms. Gabaldon threw some disjointed thoughts together to meet a publishing date she moved about 3 times.  I hope she gets her act together for the next book and starts wrapping up these story lines, stop introducing new characters and get back to what made the series so great to begin with: Jamie and Claire.  I know the tv series is taking up a lot of the author's time but I hope she can concentrate and get out a new book in a timely fashion to redeem herself on this one.  How about a lot less time looking up historical facts and more time weaving a beautiful story like we all signed up for when we paid $12.00 for this Kindle book?  It pains me to write a bad review for this.  I was so excited to read it.

I really think this is the last book in the series, despite the fact that it leaves many, many issues unresolved and half-started.  Ok, so this book sells well (and that must be why she has kept writing them) but there comes a point when you are doing more harm to your reputation than good - and this book has reached that point.  It is Boring (I read it on Kindle and kept looking to see how much I had to go; the second half of the book is particularly without a point).  And that is the real problem with this book - unlike the first 4 in the series it has no point, you never have the feeling that you are moving towards the resolution of anything...  As others have said, I read it and enjoyed it in so far as I got to see some of the characters again (although I was extremely confused about Claire's strange character developments/ depression...) but that was about it.  I have re-read the first few books in the series (up to Drums of Autumn) but none of the others, and I sure as hell won't be reading this one again!

I have been a fan of Diana Gabaldon's books since they first appeared in 1990's. However I was mildly disappointed in Echo in the Bone, but hoped that MOBY would re-establish the strengths of both main and subplots. We expect characters to become more mature and wise with age, this definitely is not the case in this book.It seems to me that it is definitely time to wrap up this series before it really undoes the brilliance of the first four / five books.  When reading this one gets the impression that the author has more important things to do than maintain the standard of the previous novels, there is so much repetition of passages etc from the previous books I cannot understand why it took 5 years to write. I am sure there was research to be done but the depth of information for the battle of Monmouth was about the same as elementary school. I had expected so much and we have received so little it is VERY disappointing. I am sorry but will not read any further books that may in future be written as I am totally disillusioned,

Jamie & Claire's story has lost its momentum. I am no longer fascinated by them because Gabaldon changed the focus of the story from these two characters to multiple others without relying heavily on Jamie & Clair to drive the plot. The crux of the problem is that she aged Jamie & Claire too much. Retire these two and chose from the family our new hero.Or because it's fiction put some more vitality in Jamie and Claire and make the next book better.

I am SO disappointed in this book!!!  I am a huge fan of this Author and this series.  I am writing this review before I even finish the book because truth be told I'm not sure I can slog through any more of it.  This book is BORING with a capital B!  I hate that this is what the series has come to.  Maybe this is why it took so long to come out.  Some one somewhere along the line had to notice just how bad this book is.  I can't imagine that so many fans gave this book 5 stars.  My best guess is they don't want to hurt the Author's feelings.  I hope if there is another book we get some of the excitement back.  If not just stop now.  I can't bear to see this series ruined any further!

What at HUGE disappointment!  I read the first five volumes in a matter of six weeks and was hooked--or so I thought.  I am not sure what happened to Gabaldon in this book, but she wanders around from one sub-plot to another with no seeming direction or purpose.  The book was so tangential as to appear meaningless.  By the end I felt quite manipulated - as if Gabaldon was strewing the pages with these various sub-plots in order to provide fodder for future volumes. Unfortunately, if that was her intention, it has backfired as far as I'm concerned.  She provided far less information about historical events or of daily life in the 18th century to hold my interest.  Plus her characters (except perhaps for Bree about whom we learn far too little) are lackluster, and any affection or respect I had for them in previous books has all but vanished.  I have no intention to ever read another book in this series!  Where was her editor?

Being a huge fan of the series for years now, I was thrilled when the book finally came out! After reading the first several chapters it became obvious for me this book was to be a disappointment. Diana Gabaldon is a wonderful writer who usually keeps her audiences spellbound. With all the other books in the series, I couldn't put the books down from beginning to end. I found myself constantly wondering throughout the reading of MOBY "what happened?".  There were way to many story lines going on at once in the book. While I understand adding new characters to keep it interesting, my real love lies with Jamie and Claire and couldn't help feeling like there were so many stories devoted to these new characters that Diana didn't spend enough on who truly matters in this series. Roger spends page after page going off to look for his father and when he finally finds him he spends all of five minutes (summed up in a couple of pages) with him and never even tells him who he is! What was the point of all those wasted pages of writing? I kept thinking wow, that could have been more Jamie and Claire time! The really disappointing part of that story was that I could not find any reason what so ever that story was even included in this book. He (the father) has no bearing on any other story line in the book what so ever. Lord John also has a story line with his family going on in this book. While I normally love him included in the series due to his past with Jamie, I felt like the whole brother/nephew thing going on here should have been in the books in the Lord John series. It just was wasted here. In the other books I also loved the details and depth of description of Claire's surgeries and battle descriptions. This book however went way overboard. It becomes apparent that in this book, unlike the others, these have just become words to fill pages. jI can't help but to wonder whether the story line well is going a bit dry for Jamie and Claire in Diana's mind. I still will be faithful to the series and I will read the next book but I truly hope Diana slows down some of the other novellas, books, publicity trips, and gets the movie thing up and going so that she can spend more dedicated time to what she does best. Jamie and Claire. Moby just gives you the feeling that Diana's busy life has put Jamie and Claire on the backburner. And that is a HUGE disappointment.

Well, after eagerly awaiting it for almost 5 years and preordering it, I was disappointed.  This time around all the surgical descriptions and medical episodes just got tedious.  Almost like filler.  It seemed to lack any of the joy and wonder of the first three novels.  Yes its set in a war but I got tired of all the battle scenes

I have been reading this series since 1993 as well as my mom. I had hoped it would have concluded with this volume however Diana seems reluctant to let her characters go. In this book we see more characters introduced, none of which she gives us enough of a glimpse to bond with. Introducing the wayward confusing plot from 1738 seemed disjointed and Solved Nothing. Yes, in life we meet many people and circumstances, however this is a book series...it shouldn't drag out as long as my own life!!!! The first few chapters had me feeling that we were finally moving forward, even knowing there was a war which would be fought. I have the Kindle version, however I wish 800 pages would have held my bond with the characters as tight as the previous seven did. This work is a frayed attempt at keeping the readers close to Diana's future volumes (and yes, I feel there will be more...based on what she didn't accomplish in this volume do you think we will get anywhere in the _next_ one?) however I am going to be one of those lost souls..apparently like Roger's father.

like so many others who waited and waited and waited for this book, I bought it early and it was delivered to my tablet on time (possibly the best part of this book). I read it as soon as it was delivered...took several days of course, but I read it from beginning to end.  The downsides:  too many characters that don't matter getting the spotlight, plots that repeat (fire in the printing house again??), gratuitous death of character (trying to ignite sympathy??), some parts L-O-N-G and drawn out and others suddenly complete (took them no time at all to finally get back to Fraser's Ridge--but they were in Savannah FORVER!).  Never once did I "swoon", never once did I stop to remind myself that this was fiction and Jamie wasn't real, never once did I stay up late into the night to finish a chapter.  Maybe it was just too long since her last book and I lost my outlander'ish love.  Maybe I just waited so long, my expectations were too high.  All I know is that I was disappointed.  I wanted to fall in love with the characters and their adventures.  I wanted to call friends and say "can you believe what happened to Claire this time??"--but I didn't.  I think I'll just wait a bit and go back and try to reread it.  Maybe it's better the second time around?

I have been a fan forever, have met Ms. Gabaldon at a book signing, have become richer because of the history she has written about and have followed the series religiously over the years as so many have. That said, the last few novels have been woefully disappointing and a quarter of the way through MOBY, I'm afraid nothing has changed. And I spend a lot of time wondering why. The first four novels were so compelling: falling through stones into the past; marrying then falling in love, writing lines like "... do ye ever get over the wanting...?" (Jamie to Claire, wedding night); rich characters like the McKenzie brothers who shared a wife; the gasp I made when Gellis revealed her vaccination scar; Brother Anselm and the Adoration ...I could go on. At the end of "Echo" where Claire "sleeps" with Lord John, it was very hard for me to understand  and now in MOBY, harder to deal with when Lord John states to Jamie (spoiler)..."we were both 'effing' you..."...really? It may be just a lack of ability to consider certain reactions to loss and pain but I've had no problem with just about everything else in this series including Black Jack's treatment of Jamie in Wentworth Prison. I've enjoyed this series SO much that I feel, now, that I've lost a good, entertaining friend and the loss is almost physical. I'll always treasure the first four and continue to read them over and over but once done with MOBY, that will be it. Yes, I'll read the last one (in ebook form, like MOBY) but am already lamenting the series demise. Maybe that's the plan....

As with thousands of other readers, I anxiously awaited the 8th book. Maybe my mistake was not rereading the last two books prior to reading this one but, I don't think it would have helped. This book did not need to be 814 pages. There were so many characters that didn't need to be in it. Roger wandering around Scotland could have been a lot shorter and meeting Geillis and Buck's interaction was just absurd. The book wandered too much with side stories. I have always enjoyed the dialogue between Jamie and Claire and just didn't get enough of Claire's dry wit in this book. OK spoiler alert...I am wondering why we weren't told how she was shot? Stray bullet, on purpose? I admit I started skipping through the book because it was becoming tedious but I did go back and try and read that section extensively and still felt it was lacking. The book could have been shorter, only because a lot of it was to far off the story. I probably won't buy the next book. Of course, in four years, I may forget the pain of this one.

I'm starting to feel like Diana is getting close to "jumping the shark" with this series.  I'm a huge fan but the series is suffering from too many characters with uninteresting plot lines and implausible coincidences.  I had to slog my way through this one and kept checking my bar on my Kindle to see how much percentage I had left.  I like Ian and Rachel but cannot stand roger and their story line. I like William but his incessant inner whining over his bastard status got old really fast. I would have liked to see more dialogue between him and Jamie but instead I had to read of William 's illogical obsession with a prostitute that he didn't even love. Se was just "under his protection"??.  Then she dies. Ok.  What was the point of that story line??  I love lord John and I think Jamie and Claire treat him horribly in this book. He saved Claire from being arrested by marrying her and Jamie can't even thank him for that??  He offers his house for Claire to set up her surgery in and she refuses??  He raised Jamie 's son for gods sake. You would think he'd deserve a bit more thanks than Jamie nearly blinding him. And all over something Jamie himself did with Mary??  Character death without any reason except maybe to elicit a tear from the reader for a paragraph or two.  Ugh.  I could go on and on with the things I did not like about this book but many have already been stated in the one star reviews. This was one of the more boring books in the series.

I'm an Outlander fan and waited like thousands of others for this book.  Totally totally totally disappointed.  146 pages to put Jamie and Claire together.  Tooooo much Lord John, Hal, and kids (this IS an Outlander series!).  Too much on sex scenes.  New characters are a total waste of reading time.  Rollos death as a main series character was so glossed over with only a page I felt cheated of grieving.  Bree came on as a whimp, Rodger as an idiot.  BTW just how did a woman with two small kids walk all that way to Lollybroch in winter? So in essence more fires, more wounded Frasers, more angry William.  Nothing new.

I have been reading this series since 2001.  I have loved the characters, the time it exists in and the storylines.  As soon as this book hit the store I was at the door.  I read it through within 2 days, so yes I am in love with Jaime and Claire.  I was soooo disappointed in this book.  After the long wait, in my opinion,  it was thrown together just to get it out there. I am not interested in medical details and give it up on the war thing, we know how it ends.  I wanted to see something more on Brian and how did Brianna and her family travel only 40 years to wear Jaime and Claire were.  I know thats probably going to be in the next book...and what happened to Buck.  Nothing is ever explained about what Jem experiences in the train tunnel.  I think the war and medical descriptions could have been cut back and more of the "story" developed.  I am still a fan and always will be, but this one let me down.

I was so disappointed!  No way would anyone be able to make heads or tails of this without reading or re-reading the first six.  The small vignettes to introduce some events only made your head spin.  I LOVED the other books and waited and waited for this one.  Too much needless mentions like running into the fellow who raped Claire.  The war chapters were so drawn out and only confused me more.  I am going to read book 6 and then try again with 7.  Also, an epilogue 50 years later consisting of someone reading grave markers of the Frazers would be a nice wrap up.

I don't know what to say about this book except: why bother?  I love Gabaldon's Outlander series and have been a faithful reader for many years, her style of writing has been as much a draw for as the plots and characters.  This book started out reminiscent of a bad soap opera and only after many chapters did I finally see Gabaldon's style.  I could have done without all the "Grey's" as well as the "honeymoon" chapters.  Totally unnecessary.  I really hope the next book is a "true" outlander book....because this one wasn't.

I really love Diana Gabaldon's writing. She's very clever, witty, and manages to create characters that resonate with me for all sorts of reasons. And I really want to know what happens in the end with Jamie and Claire (does she go back to her own time as an old woman? Does that mean that Jamie will die first?). BUT - the writing process that Gabaldon has spoken about so often is really obvious in these last few books. She writes in small, apparently disconnected stories that eventually all join up and voila - a book. It seems to me that this actually means that multiple plot lines are started and not finished, that some mini-stories are just gratuitous, and that in the end the book doesn't actually go anywhere. In terms of the whole big storyline, this book achieves only a couple of key points and leaves some central characters in limbo AGAIN. I'm irritable about it because I know I'm going to keep buying her books just to find out what happens in the end - but I'm increasingly resentful about it.

I can't believe this book has a 4.5 rating?  I have read all of DG's previous novels, I have the Outlander companion and look forward to the TV series.  It would be redundant of me to rehash other poster's comments so I will just say read most of the 2 and 3 star reviews which report the plodding, padded and rambling prose which does nothing to further the plot line.  Yes, it's nice to enter the comfortable Outlander world again, but when I start skimming several chapters trying to find an ounce of story movement, I know this isn't quality writing.  I beg DG to end this series. It has run it's course and the never ending list of new characters introduced is watering down our Claire and Jamie story. The characters flit through time, meeting family members as if it's a natural occurrence.  Maybe Bree, Roger and the kids could get their own Tardis and join Dr. WHO on adventures?  Jaime is like the Travelocity gnome-look here I am with General Washington, here's me with Benedict Arnold-these are gimmicks that don't help with the storyline.  The book isn't bad and many parts are enjoyable, but get it at the library- don't waste your money.

I am one of those who will read whatever Ms. Gabaldon writes because she is an excellent author.  Like millions, I am a huge fan of the entire Outlander genre.  But, this installment, having waited so very long for it, left me flat.  I don't mind all the detail of parts of her stories; she has taught me a great deal from her researched stories.  But, like many have noted, the second half of the book feels rushed with large holes in the telling and that's a major problem.  I would have liked to have been there for the settling of Marsali and Fergus in Charleston and wonder why there instead of a large city closer to the Ridge.  I would have liked to have been there for the trek out of Savannah homeward to the Ridge.  I would have liked to have been there for the conversations between Bree and Roger and the planning for how to successfully jump the family 40 years forward in time to get them back to the Ridge with Jamie and Claire.  I would have liked to have heard more about Bree and the children meeting Brian.  I would have liked to know what happened with Buck.  I would like to have walked away with William as he disappears on his own and heard him begin to rethink his paternity.  I have no trouble with meeting so many new characters; if you enjoy Jamie and Claire's world, you should want to meet the people with whom they interact...but there are just too many holes in the story when it comes to the central characters we have come to love.  There's no question, that in her next book (because by now we know there must be a next novel,) Ms. Gabaldon will most likely weave some of these holes together; answer questions; continue the life threads of those we have so learned to love, but it will take years for that.  And, it's the time it takes to create her next book that is becoming frustrating to the reader, especially when she leaves so many holes in the story we have currently to consider.  And, that's really too bad.  I wanted to love it, and I am just left feeling deflated and uninspired.

Am about 300 pages into Ms. Gabaldon's latest and can say that I'm extremely thankful for my public library. Have to agree with the others here who have called out the ridiculously meandering, pointless digressions in this saggy, baggy addition to the Outlander series. I'd thought the Fiery Cross was bad but this one might be worse. Besides all of the stupid characters & their feckless behaviors who've come to clutter up this fictional landscape, there are way too many descriptions of historical events. Ms. Gabaldon, if I wanted to know about the Battle of Monmouth, I'd consult an actual history book or even real records from that time period -- I would NOT consider you or your fiction to be an authority on such subjects. Please stop larding your books with tediously drawn out descriptions of historical events. If you really can't think up any more plot points for the main characters you've been working with for so long, then just end the series, please. You are dishonoring your own work with these poorly done excuses for sequels.

Nothing- that's what happened. I waited five years for this??? I'm only half way through and I'm ready to quit! I used to tell people that this was my favorite book series. Well after this eighth one- I 'm not sure I can wait for anymore installments. What a snooze- where is the Diana Gabaldon that I loved?

I waited a long time for this book and I am disappointed. I am halfway through the book because I SKIPPED a lot of the boring dialog. I will try to re-read the first half after I slog through the rest of the book. I know that I read how one character was missing and then all of a sudden there he is as if he wasn't missing. It has taken half the book to go through less than a week of days. I don't care about Lord John or Hal or William's whores. This is the Jamie and Claire series, not the Lord John series, so enough about Lord John! I certainly hope Diana Gabaldon reads ALL her reviews and not just the 4 and 5 star reviews. Maybe she has too much that she is doing and can't concentrate on her bread and butter series, instead of those stupid novellas she has been writing.

This book needed a better editor. Or at least someone who was vetting the story, not just calculating the dollar signs. The story was an unfortunate balance between too much and not enough at the same time, which was not only unsatisfying, but sadly boring. All the main characters were present but the reader gets only glimpses of who they are now. The storyline felt rushed except when it was excruciatingly slow. I was fortunate to have read the first seven books back-to-back and never before experienced boredom reading this series - by the end of this installment, I was scanning the pages to see if anything interesting was going on. Even the Jamie/Claire segments were thin and repetitive. I wanted to love this book, but really didn't even like it.  The story was barely advanced except for some marriages, babies and the occasional score-settling. The ending was lame and predictable. On another point, I am not enthusiastic about the casting for the tv series - the whole time I read this book, i could only picture the tv actors as Jamie and Claire and it just didn't work for me. I liked my imagination better - especially Claire's character. What a mess...

I thought it was just me until I started reading some of the other reviews. I have loved this series from book one, and in 2009 I reread the entire series before the next book came out. I was totally lost when I started this one and must have forgotten a whole lot of the previous one -yes, it's been 5 yrs and I've read 400-500 books since then, but it just wasn't making sense. The story hops all over the place between characters and centuries, and is very hard to keep up with. I still have about 100 pages to go and the last 100 or so have gotten a whole lot more interesting. The ending of this book will determine whether or not I read the next one. (if I'm still alive  by then). Had the first ones been this disjointed, I'd have likely never read the rest. This is my least favorite of all of them. In fairness to the author, it's got to be difficult to turn out 800 plus page books every few years and keep it interesting.

Oh boy! I was sooo disappointed in this book.  It is truly bad.  And to have waited years to read this mash up made it worse .  I have totally enjoyed this series.  Claire and Jamie and all their extended families have entertained me throughout the years.  I have always admired the way Gabaldon has woven their story with the history of the period.  This installment however was poorly written, overly long, and seemed designed at points to capture the readers of "Fifty Shades of Gray"!  There are also two very distinct storylines going on in the book, I guess to remind us about the time travel aspect of these stories.  But one gets totally dropped for literally hundreds of pages to be picked up late in the book in preparation for yet another installment of this saga to come 4 years from now!!!!  Save your time -- here it the upshot ... Jamie and Claire meet George Washington and for a time live in Philly and New Jersey together... end of story ... Hopefully Gabaldon reads her reviews and when she undertakes to write the next installment will be a little more succinct and a little less explicit!

The first book was magic.  The focus was on Jamie and Claire and it was absolute magic.  I enjoyed the series.  This book was really a couple of different books jammed into one.  Going back and forth between past and present did not work for me in this book.  It was jarring.  I really just wanted to stay with Jamie and Claire.  Old, young, it does not matter.  They would be enjoyable even if the whole book was hem having a conversation from their rocking chairs, I really felt that there was just too much and there needed to be editing. Bree and Roger could have probably gone into another book. Honestly, I really don't care about Williams character.  He does not have the same charisma that Jamie has.

While the characters are, as usual, vividly and beautifully alive, nothing of any great note is resolved in this latest installment of the series. There is excessive and tedious attention paid to the events of the revolutionary war, which, if we're honest, is not what most of Ms. Gabaldons readers bought the book for. To know that we will probably have to wait another four years to uncover what we've already waited four years for is disappointing to say the least.

A lot happened but NOT a lot happened. For instance, it takes the ENTIRE BOOK for certain confrontations to occur that you've been waiting to happen since the last book. This constant, horribly frustrating delaying tactic makes me think (fear that) the author is drying up...running out of things to say or stories to tell us (heaven forbid). I hope the sycophantic fans and the coming cable series isn't causing her to under achieve, like I've seen happen before with Charlaine Harris; writing in autopilot after the series reached the small screen. I certainly hope not, because this series has been one of the very best up until this point...a LITTLE overly gratuitously prurient for my taste but still very good. The story seems to DRAG...and not much happens that is important. I hope this is just a one book issue and not a growing trend. Maybe she's stretching herself too thin being so involved with the TV series (which I hope pays off in the end with a series that is worthy of the books it's based upon instead of what usually happens) at the same time as writing the book? Let's hope with the series well under way now that she can focus now on the next book...and give us another GREAT book instead of a mediocre one. She hasn't lost me YET as a reader...I fully expect (hope? Pray?) this to be a one-book thing.

D.G. Closes her wonderful tale so out of character to her previous books.  She seems to rush from one character to the next simply in order to dispose of them.  This most beautiful love story ends void of any feeling.  MOBY lacks the great story telling and care we have come to expect.

I've read all the books several times and really enjoyed them.  This was the hardest book to get through - not worth the wait or the price.  As others have pointed out, it was repetitive and BORING!  I'm done with D.G. books!  If I could give NO STARS, I would.

This book should not have taken years to write. Diana Gabaldon has clearly run out of ideas or is just in it for the money at this point. There was almost no story at all and what there was lacked depth and passion. I was beyond disappointed. The epic saga of Jamie and Claire Fraser deserved better. Diana Gabaldons time would have been better spent figuring out how to give Jamie and Claire an amazing ending. Saying goodbye to the Fraser clan would have been sad but preferable to having the wonderful Outlander series go to crap.

Absolutely loved the Outlander books up until The Fiery Cross then it all went down hill for me. Lord John, William and the army characters bored me and I found myself planning tea and skipping pages until I bypassed the army twaddle. Jamie and Claire still captivated me but this book rambled on a bit and in the end I was just reading it for the sake of finishing it and nothing about the enjoyment. I must say the first books were amazing and I don't think I will ever find another book that will consume and absorb me the way the Outlander books did up until The Fiery Cross.

I was captivated by the first few books in the series, and appreciate the author being able to create such vivid characters.  This novel however is very dull.  I felt as though the author wrote several short stores and inserted them to break up the dull arc of Claire and Jamies story.  I was most interested in Ian Murray - his story added quite a bit of depth to the character.  I agree with another viewer that there was no point in including Ben Grey.  No interest in including Roger's "experiences" while searching for Jem.  While I'm on that section of the story, what was the point of it?  Such a big build up, supposed terror, and to have it end the way it did?  Don't want to reveal spoilers.  I read the book over a week, mostly because I didn't particularly care about the characters.  I'm a bit tired of Claire, who seems to have become even more impressed with herself and her knowledge.  Hey, guess we'd all be a genius if we went back 200 years - eh?  I get that her training as a physician does make her special, but always wondered at the choice of surgeries the author chooses to include.  What was the point of including the surgery of the mulatto slave girl?  Again, another random story - written and inserted.  I'm not really interested in finding out the eventual 'ending'  for me the series has already ended.

I devoured the first Outlander novels. They were beautiful! But somewhere along the way, the stories became too contrived, too violent, too overly developed, too busy.  DG has jumped the shark on this one! Not only has she brought almost every character ever introduced into WiMOHB, but introduced even more.  Add on top of that yet another time zone  - that we didn't really need to visit and another generation we already knew well enough for the sake of the story.  Too much:  too much time developing characters we don't need, too much violence/rape for the sake of not sure what; too much for the sake of nothing gained.  I ended up skimming through Echo just to get through it (and don't think I missed much); now this one.  Is this all Outlander has become?  Tedious and disappointing.

I was very disappointed in this book.  In this series, I have liked some books more than others but I really did not enjoy this book.  When the last book ended James and Claire reunite and then James takes off with John to pummel him for having sex with Claire.  When this book started I couldn't wait to finally go back to reading about Claire and James.  But it dragged on for many chapters before they are reunited.  I pretty much skimmed a lot of this book and would suggests to Diane to stick to one love story and then if the reader wants to read about other characters in the story, then write a series about them.  How many books are there going to be in this series because if it is another four years that we find out how James ends up in the future before Claire ever meets him?

I will give it two stars only because I am a huge fan of the series. I have read them all at least twice. I can't even get thru this read. I, along with thousands of you, waited much too long for this last book. I wish I could say it was worth the wait, but it was a huge let down. I felt like she just kept writing hoping to get somewhere with this plot, or to make it last longer to justify her not finishing it sooner.....With time travel at her finger tips her options to keep this series going was endless!  It was so boring at times that I found myself skipping chapters. I am not a writer but I think I will end this series in my own head with my own version, which couldn't be worse than this. I am done!

Like other fans of the Outlander series, I counted the days till this most recent novel was published.  I purchased my copy the day it came out.  However, as much as I hate to say it, I found this chapter in the Outlander story to be quite disappointing.  It felt disjointed, hopping from one storyline to another, none of them really doing anything to move the story forward in any significant way.  I found problems in story continuity and the forays into the quantum physics of time travel and graphic explanations of surgery procedures to be totally unnecessary to the story at hand.  If there is to be another book in the series, I hope it has more focus and more of the magic of the earlier novels.

There is a saying among the Sufis: "The soup of the soup of the soup of the soup". Alas, the author has also kept adding water to the same batch of soup and the result is a watered down effort. The book holds the reader more out of curiosity than good tasty reading. We only want to know what happens to the characters. Like the author of the Harry Potter series, this author needs to stop cranking out the soap opera. Her own real skills that she displayed in the first book are crying out for her to do some real writing again. Even if it isn't an instant best seller, the author must write something new for her own health.

I miss the old books that held me at every page. Turned and turned all 800 pages hoping it would get better, looking for some plot to follow but everything was a mishmash of characters (favorites and nobodies) and historical filler.  Basically all the two and one star reviews capture my feelings better than I could accurately state myself, but as the thousands flock to give it 4 and 5 stars out of loyalty, I felt as a loyal follower ( I reread the series just so I could start right into MOBY) I had to voice my opinion that the series isn't what it used to be

What a piece of crap! This book is a total waste of time and money. I agree with other posts that say to just read the last two pages. I found it so very boring that I just skipped whole sections. The characters weren't true to how they were established in earlier books; Claire couldn't be more irritating; Jamie is different; the dog that was so important to Ian dies and it is no big deal. I could go on but then I'll be as boring as DG.

This book unfortunately was not up to par with prior books in this series. Chapters felt disjointed. Many plot lines were lengthy and unnecessary to the book as a whole while other story lines and characthers were disposed of in an abrupt and unsatisfying manner.All in all, this book displayed a serious lack of continuity with previous stories in the series and was a spectacularly uninspiring addition to the collection.

Disappointing.  Repetitive (themes, action, even dialog) - reusing material from previous novels.  The whole series has become like cloth worn thin.  When 'companionable silence' was used in Outlander it was effective, using it 3 times in this book seems lazy.  Plot is shambling.  She draws some scenes in minute detail, then picks up the characters months later in different locations.  Nothing I'd re-read.

I want to know how Bree and family made it back to Fraser's ridge.  what happened to William and the Grey family, Dottie, Marsalis and Fergus and their families. Who Richardson really is and why he is after the Grey family?  love the books, can't wait for the tv series. I just wasn't ready for the book to end. I still have too many unanswered questions.

I was so disappointed...  I found it confusing and boring.  I had been looking forward to the new book coming out and I then I had to force myself to keep reading it, thinking that it would get better...but it didn't.

I'm sure I'm not alone when I admit that I have been chasing the high since Outlander was first released...and it just isn't to be found. By book #8 the thrilling and captivating story of Jamie and Claire has become so diluted with unnecessary characters, popping in and out of the story in various locations and time periods, that - despite masterful writing and attention to detail - my craving is not even close to satisfied. Diana Gabaldon has produced an admirable work of fiction but I found myself skimming through the less intriguing storylines (Brianna and Roger: yawn. Quakers? Thee must be kidding) to get to 'the good parts'. As with George R.R. Martin's Game of Thrones, I will keep reading (loyalty demands it) but I feel that the story has lost its way, and some of its magic.

After discovering the whole series early January, 2014 and reading them to pass the horrific winter, I was hooked and anticipated this last book. Wasted my money buying a hard cover.  What a disappointment!  The bag is gone.  Too much sex.  In the previous books there was just enough sex to spice things up.  This one reads almost like a cheap romantic novel.  Too many things are left hanging, too much hocus pocus, and how do Brianna, Roger and the children make it back from 1739 to 1778 when traveling through the stones is so horrific?  Time to end and tie things together.  I will admit if there is ninth novel, I would probably read it just to see what happens, but will not be waiting with baited breath.

Way too much rambling.  Yet again Claire saves the day.  I am almost ready for Diana Gabaldon to just write her out of the books but that won't happen.  Please stop starting plot lines and cutting them off, leaving us to wonder for another four years.  I started out loving the Outlander books but the last few have been sorely lacking.  At this point lets just wrap up the Fraser's story.

Disappointing. My husband and I are avid Outlander fans and after reading this book that's the one word descriptor we instantly and individually came to. We waited years for nothing. The story line was flat. I guess everyone has a bad piece now and then so Diana will too. I've read all The Lord John series, the novellas that come out, the Outlander companion, even the graphic novel and this book is by a long shot the dullest, least intriguing. Looking forward with hopeful anticipation to the next book.

I agree with the negative reviews on this book. I'm a huge Gabaldon fan BUT this book leaves a lot to be desired. I too was bored and found it rambling at best. It seems like it's thoughts for the book stuck away in a drawer only to be put togather in a book as a last minute thought. Too little, too long AND too late seems like the best description!

I was disappointed with this book because it seemed as though the author's "heart's blood" was not in it. It reads more like a screen play. I was afraid that the Starz television treatment would harm the books and it seems as though it has. Well thanks for six really good books Ms. Gabaldon, I will like them forever.
Too much war: ending not tied up.  I waited for this for years, to no avail.  Disappointed!!
After waiting so long and for 12bucks. I couldn't be more disappointed.  There wasn't even a story to tell. FROM the first chapter you knew the ending. I'm glad it's over.

I have loved the outlander series from ten minutes into the first book but find written in my own heart's blood way to wordy and way too short on content.  I pre=ordered the book so that I would have it the second Amazon released it and I'm a third of the way through.  That's not normal as I'd not normally not put it down except to get the odd hour of sleep here and there from page one to the end.  I find myself wondering "who wrote this book?"  Doesn't sound like Diana Gabaldon or maybe I've simple read enough about the Claire and her family.

Loved the first six, stuck with the seventh, ground my way through this one.  Five year effort - five month product.  They say that every writer has three good books.  I guess that DG exceeded that mark.

After waiting impatiently for some years I'm sorry to say that I have been bored, bored bored with almost every Chapter except those written In a more crisp style, the adventures of Bree and Family. I am not interested in the tedious day to day descriptions of proposed life with the Continental Army, nor the intimate unnecessary sex scenes. Very like happens I this long long saga and very little has happened with the previous several books, ho hum.  Get back to the first books and I'm all in. Thanks.

I am an avid Outlander series fan and I have to admit "Fiery Cross" and "Outlander" were my favorite two books. I am not much interested in Gabaldon's departure from the story of Jamie and Claire and this bizarre time traveling tangent she's gone on with Roger, Brianna, Jem, and Mandy. I was nearly cross-eyed with boredom thumbing through some of the chapters and found the inundation of new characters dizzying. Even the romantic scenes felt boilerplate. All-in-all, I was thoroughly unimpressed with this book.

Ms. Gabaldon is a talented and captivating story teller, thus bringing it up to the two stars.  However, this episode came off as a soap opera, not a novel.  The ending was completely predictable, even though it was supposed to be a "cliffhanger" obviously leading to the next book.  I'm sure that those who read romance novels with the pictures of strong young men without shirts, and beautiful damsels clinging to them on the cover will enjoy it.

This, the 8th book in the Outlander series by Diana Gabaldon is fantastic!  Well, all her books are but this one was deeply touching.  It beautifully captures Claire and Jamie as they experience the joys and frustrations of aging.  This is very hard to do to characters....allow them to be mortal, but she does it with the greatest respect for her characters!  Don't start with this book though.  A new reader must read all 7 volumes first and then this one!

Diana Gabaldon is a very talented writer, but the characters have no growth left in them. There's no real plot, just the dozen or so people wandering about bouncing into each other with little conflict or purpose. There are characters and back-story that I just don't remember from past books, sorry, and it feels like I'm expected to. It is very easy to put down. Any given chapter is fun to read, but that's it.

I had looked forward to the book for a long time, but it was very short on plot, and simply consisted of battle after battle description with very little character development.  In addition, a little backstory would be helpful, for those of us who do not remember every detail of books read years ago.  The first two books of this series were fantastic.

While this wraps up the story lines well enough, I think there was a lot of verbiage that could have been edited out to make the story flow more smoothly; there is a fine balance between "enough" explanation to carry the story and too much, which gets tedious in a larger story, especially one with so many story lines to draw together in only one volume.

I loved the first few Outlander books, but seriously, why are so many people giving this 5 stars? There are too many new characters that never really develop into a storyline worth reading (Jane, Fanny). The main characters don't seem to be the same people they once were. The supporting characters (Fergus, Marsali, William) never see any "action" at all! I didn't feel like there was much expansion in the story of Roger, Bree and family. The story of the slave girl and the death of Henri was not even woven into the fabric of any storyline. If Gabaldon wants to keep things fresh for the next novel, she needs to cut out unnecessary characters and stick to the ones the readers want to see. I did really appreciate the historic details and descriptive scenes she is best known for.

Wont get too into it so i dont spoil it for the ones who haven't read it yet but i'm kinda disappointed. I love the outlander series due to the emotion the writing draws from me. I'm usually laughing and crying right along with the characters, and while this book has sad moments, I didn't feel anything. I also can't believe it took Diana 4 years to write that. I don't see anything in that book that would have needed the extensive research she's needed for the other books. Maybe I'm just disappointed because I waited so SO long for this book, only to be left feeling "meh" about it. I'm at a loss because Diana is SUCH a great author. I expected so much more.

But it seems like we are just treading water. Claire and Jamie keep going through ridiculously contrived situations and rarely seem to make any progress toward where they want to be. As much as I like the many characters, it might be time to wrap up this series instead of dragging it out too long.

Right now I could care less about what happens to this family unless the author can go back to her original style of writing which she seems to have lost about 3 books ago.  Way too much filler about sounds, smells, thoughts, medical specifics, etc.  Way too much whining from William about discovering he is a "Bastard". His world will not fall apart unless he empowers it to do so. The most enjoyable part was at the very end - the return to Fraser's ridge and the arrival of Brianna and her family. This should have occurred mid way and the last 200 pages should have taken off from that point.  The basic facts of this story could have been shortened and written in a novel about 1/3 the size.

I have read the outlander series three times through and loved them. I waited patiently for her next installment, I don't expect her to bang out an 800 page novel in a day. This piece had so many characters, old and new, it felt disjointed, didn't really get to know them or really care what happened to them. The whole section of Sophriana and the surgery didn't even feel like the same book, and the prophecy, where did that come from and why?. Overall just disappointed. Still give it three stars because I love the main characters.

Roughly halfway into this book and thinking there must be something seriously wrong with me, I decided to check out what other readers had to say in this review section.  Thank you all for validating so articulately how I feel.  This book bores me to death.  I love Outlander and all the books up until now, but this one is horrifically BORING.  I can't stand any more of it.  This is the first DG book I will not waste any more time reading.  Diana, what were you thinking when you wrote this boring travesty?

Long, confusing beginning with time jumps and parallel stories and ridiculous incidents (like the fight between Jamie and John and William).  Felt like some one else actually wrote the book.  Very disappointing.
Compared to her other books, this one seemed boring. It's very slow moving, almost like she is purposefully trying to delay action to write more books.

Let me start by saying I LOVED the first 6 books. So much so that I can't decide which one is my favorite. The character building, historical events and flow is absolute perfection. And then there's An Echo in Bone, which I did not care for and that left off with several cliff hangers that were to be continued in MOBY. I have to say if you were like me and you didn't care for Book 7, then you're not going to like book 8. It's very obvious that DB had other things on her mind when she was writing the last 2 books. MOBY was disjointed, the character building was poor at best, and perspectives of many new characters were incorporated, which I didn't care for at all. I love hearing about Roger and Bree and the kids, and of course Jamie and Claire but there was much time spent on Lord John's point of view, while I enjoy his wit if I wanted to hear it I'd read the Lord john books. There was also a lot of focus on the descriptions of battles, which seems more of a way to fill in the pages, rather than advance the story. While the descriptions were wonderful in the first 6 books they always focused on things from one of the main characters perspectives and added to the character building. In this case the battle descriptions serve more to show off the research that has gone into the book.  Several of the plots were unfinished as well, and not on a cliff hanger kind of way. I often found myself flipping back to see if I missed something when the characters were talking because the dialog was so disjointed I had no idea what they were talking about. DB has also incorporated a new Gallic saying 'A Dhia' which I don't remember hearing in any of the other books and was said repeatedly in this book, for no apparent reason. Unfortunately, unlike an Echo in Bone in which I still wanted to read more (even though I didn't care for it), MOBY left me with no desire to read another one. That being said I probably will just to see where the characters go, thankfully I won't be holding my breath waiting for it to come out. Hopefully DB takes the time to focus on the characters that have brought her this far in the first place, instead of seemingly putting them on the back burner while she works on her other projects and then rushing to finish the book as she appears to have done with MOBY.

This series should have ended a very long time ago. The first, second, and fourth books were quite good (the third was preposterous). I struggled to get through this as I did everything since Drums of Autumn.I love Jaime and Claire, but Diana has made them unwelcome guests who don't know when to leave.

I am a fan of this series and have eagerly awaited each new book. The latest installment certainly moves the characters stories along, albeit leaving the reader with more questions as to "what happens next?" I agree with other readers that this book in certainly choppy in sections and blithely skips over explanations. Not to have spoiler alerts, but was Brian Fraser left unconscious in the cemetery in the middle of winter? Where was the conversation that Bree & Roger would skip 40 years ahead to her mother's current time? How did they do it w/no gems? What happened to Buck? One minute there reuniting near Lallybroch and the next they're on the Fraser's Ridge? William's constantly lamenting about his parentage was excessive. Now there are members of Hal's family in jeopardy. Like others I quickly realized a little more than half way through that with all these loose threads there was NOT going to be an end to the story at this time. That was very disappointing.  As I said, I'm a fan of the series, but all good things must come to and end.  Having readers wait 3-5 years for the next book is not only a disservice to those who have followed the series, but smacks of greed and is beyond ridiculous.  I appreciate the author's research into the history of the period.  Frankly, though, I am an educated person and had I wanted to delve into American history, I would have purchased a book on that specific subject (ergo: "Echo in the Bone" was tedious).  The first book was published in 1991 and it's now been 23 years to get to book eight.  As another reviewer put it: "I don't think I'll live long enough to see the end" ... if there ever is one?

After reading all the Outlander series I awaited the last book impatiently. It was rather disappointing. I have the impression that the author was a bit tiered of the story and after making the characters go through the usual mishaps, variations on earlier adventures, she ended with a feel good reuniting of the family. It was indeed enough, and I am happy it ended that way. I couldn't put down the other volumes and  each time I finished one, I was sucked into the next one like an addict, but this last book was a little weak.

Hmm. I have" binge" read the series over the past few months but have been disappointed since book 4. I just don't care anymore. I feel incredibly bored with the characters. SOME SPOILERS AHEAD. Honestly, the only ones I care about are Claire and Jamie, and we only get a glimpse into their lives anymore with all the changing point of view. I don't care about William. I barely care about Brianna, and even Claire and Jamie have dissolved into reminiscing about their former lives, not what their lives are now. Is this is the consequences of having characters that age? I don't think so. I think it is more a question of writing. I'm hoping the new series on TV will renew my interest, but until then I think I will retire this book. It's just not worth finishing. UPDATE - I forced myself to finish the book yesterday. I am still just as disappointed. Frankly, Diana needed to end this series after "Voyager". Everything is now recycled - plotlines, characters, descriptions, feelings, the list goes on and on. I'm also disturbed by Gabaldon's use of rape as a go-to plot device. I think she should spend some time in her years of research at a counseling center - because her characters' feelings and reactions are trivial and complete bs. Jenny advised her raped daughter to pretend like everything was ok to keep peace in the family?  This is not the Jenny we have known and it's disgusting.  What a waste of a good series.

How did this take five years to write? Was it the myriad of google searches on 18th century surgical techniques? Nothing happened in this novel.  The plot summary is one paragraph.  Why would a British Lord care about a young whore, why would he care about his bio father, this sort of thing was fairly routine in society.  This series is starting to resemble Forrest Gump in the number of "coincidental" meetings with historic figures.  Diane-get back to basics or stop.
Compared to the other 7 novels in this series, this was the first one I read and thought "Meh".

I do hope that there will be a 9th book in this series.  I was introduced to the series in early 2014, and have not been able to put any of the books down until it was read.  I read each one slowly so that I would not miss any exciting moment.  Nothing has mesmerized me since reading the Harry Potter Series.  I have something to live for.  I will be celebrating my 81st birthday in and few days.  So I will continue studying philosophy, reading Diana's books  and continuing my Silver slipper exercise program at Curves.  I highly recommend any of Diana's writings for all over 18.
Way too much time spent the Revolutionary War. I think I am finally ready to see an end to this saga.

Spoiler Alert!  My least favorite of the series!  Too many characters added. No purpose in Jane and Fanny! I found myself skimming through so many parts. Buck knowing Geillis was his mother but not caring was absurd! Kind of tired of rape being part of each book.  When it was supposed that Jamie killed Martha's husband, (the sole surviver of the the many men who gang raped Clair) it was so calmly talked about, you could almost imagine them eating tea and biscuits.  I love the main characters, but I think it's time to wrap up the series.

I am a diehard fan of this series, have read them all, some repeatedly, since the early 00's. I've read the novellas, checked out the websites, Outlander is easily in the top three of my 'go-to' books that I refer people to read. However, with this book, I think this series jumped the shark. Too many random other characters, too much Battle of Monmouth, not enough of the main family and Roger and Brianna. I don't want to go into details and risk spoiling, but I think this might be the last one of the series I read!
but it's not the best in the series. I felt like I was reading a series of sound bites that were strung together. That said, I did enjoy it.

A continuation of what must be some of the finest writing and wonderfully real characters in any books I've ever read.  What can I say except that I've been reading this series now for over 20 years.  A new book comes out about every 5 years, and I'm first on line to buy the new one.  Even with a copy on my Kindle, I must have the hard cover edition for my library.  It will be a sad day when Ms. Gabaldon finally ends her Outlander series.

This book was unlike any other of her books. I was slightly disappointed with this book's storyline.  I believe the most exciting and interesting parts were with Jamie, Claire, Brianna, and Roger. There was too much, for my liking,  on William, John and other characters that I pretty much skipped pages.  In a nutshell,  I did like this book,  but LOVED the previous books of this series.

Another great book in the Outlander series!  Lots of back and forth with Jamie, Claire, Brianna, Roger, Lord John and his 'son' William. Story is interwoven with Diana's usual talent. Without being a spoiler, the ending leaves you panting for the next book.  I'm hoping Starz TV continues their series and turns all the books into movies.

I was very disappointed with this book.  As other reviews have mentioned, the book dragged on and on, and very little actually happened.  It was definitely not worth a five year wait.  However, I am now so invested in the series, I will wait (im)patiently for the next (how many?) books in the series.

First let me say that I'm an Outlander addict.  I've read all other 7 of the books 3 or 4 times (also read Lord John books).  With that said, I found this book very disappointing.  It was full of fluff with characters introduced and dropped.  The short chapters switched to many different characters too quickly.  It felt disjointed to me.  I really wanted to like this book and was waiting a long time for it to come out and am very sad after reading it.

The title provokes the imagination, making it keep one's own heart on the look out for tragedy, but no, she just hypnotises the reader from the get go with her fabulous skill and there is nothing to be afraid of, you are back in her world.  This eighth volume whips the reader along the terrifying road of revolution and war in America, while keeping a watchful eye on the never dull Brianna and Roger situation in modern day Lallybroch.  Diana Gabaldon's narrative and those funny, out-of-the-side-of-her-mouth modern sayings she is fond of putting into Claire's irreverent mouth, are a little more hip and common in this book, which I liked. I could've done without Natty Bumpo.  It's one thing to write your own historical fiction, but to use another writer's characters from another historical fiction, well, it just seems a bit too much.  it doesn't make any difference in the long run. Diana Gabaldon is a stupendous storyteller who has lost not one nano ounce of her power in this eighth volume.  I was so happy and relieved when I read the way she closed this book.  If, when, she decides to end this tremendous odyssey of Jamie and Claire, it will be with my own heart's blood.  She has given historical fiction one hell of a whopping gift and it seems the film of these stories will be a similar success. An ironic aspect of Gabaldon's writing is that so many people who would otherwise have absolutely adored this Scottish / American historical tale, older readers from a history loving generation, wont read it because of the graphic sex, common throughout all the stories. It isn't just a shame for prudish readers, it's a shame that the overall impact of these great books are actually mathematically limited because this puts such a huge generation of people off. In my daydreams, I can present a sanitized version of these 8 volumes of wonderful stories to my mother for Christmas, but alas, these are modern times and sex is everywhere...timid readers beware.

As the next installment in a long series of hefty books, this is more of what we have come to know, expect and love from the exceptionally talented Ms. Gabaldon.  The storyline is filled with twists so improbable as to be worthy of Dickens or Shakespeare, but, as with those other authors, the improbability is an irrelevance.  What matters are the characters -- finely, beautifully and lovingly drawn.  Young Ian, gifted with knowledge of who and what he is, strong enough to get through the clash of cultures that has defined his life; Rachel and Denny, the devout, outcast Quakers, the Aristocratic, impetuous and honorable Greys, William and Brianna, young adults learning to adjust to rude truths about their parentage, and plenty more besides.  But above all, it is the love story of Jamie and Claire that fires all the books and keeps us coming back.  I actually enjoy these later books even more than I enjoyed Outlander, largely because Claire and Jamie are now my age -- and they act like it in every way.  But neither their strength and maturity, nor the infirmities that come with a few extra decades, have diminished their devotion and commitment to each other, nor has it turned them into unsexed lumps.  Most romance in fiction stays rigidly focused on young love; it is refreshing to find an author who appreciates that romance, and sex, is not just for those with perfect, youthful bodies.  She makes the characters solid and believable in circumstances that involve the wildly improbable.  And not just believable.  They aren't just people who seem real, they are people we could actually like and care about.  And that makes each of her books satisfying and enjoyable.  Well,that and the fact that she has a real genius when it comes to writing dialog -- the author she reminds me most of in that respect is the late Patrick O'Brien, and that is high praise indeed.

A few years ago, I read all of Diana Gabaldon's books, eagerly awaited new ones, reread most, and recommended them to everyone.  I participated in her Compuserve forum and was caught up in the discussions there.  I was even anxious to read this one, after five years of waiting for it, and in spite of my absolute anger with the closing of the prior book.  That one left almost every one of her lovable characters in some sort of cliff hanging horror, and we all knew that it took her four or five years to complete the next one...partly because she is always writing smaller books involving these characters in the intervening years.  I weaned myself away from her forum and the intervening books, the small excerpts she releases in order to hold interest, and so on.  But when this book was finally released, I bought it and read it immediately.  It is a good book, definitely worth reading, but for whatever reason, I did not think much of it equal to her earlier writing.  Long stretches of it are pure history with little actually happening to her characters.  Some of the conversation is a good as before, but much is not.  I was bothered by the constant switching between stories of the different characters, and sometimes was not quite sure who was speaking. It seems most improbable that these Scottish highlanders would have had intimate contact and friendship with every important person involved in the Revolutionary War.  I am disappointed in this book,, even though I consider it good.  Will I read the next one?  Probably.  I still love the characters and still want to see what they do, but is it really worth waiting five years?  I'm not sure about that!
fragmented, confusing and just plain boring.  As a fan of the earlier books I found that by the end I just didn't care what happened or not.

I love the Outlander Series, but I fear Dr. Gabaldon is getting tired. The formula is still at work: sex, violence, history, repeat, but somehow it feels more contrived in this latest rendering. That said, I will still read all in the series that gets published ( and in the Lord John Grey series). The author has done a great job of making time travel acceptable to this skeptic and I have loved watching the central characters age in two different centuries.

I took my time with this book deliberately because I have been waiting for it for years and this is always a really special treat to have a new Outlander book.  Diana is magnificent in how she does her research and how much she puts into a book that you can see why it takes so long to put this together, that does not mean my own greedy heart does not wish it was faster but I do understand and can see why it takes so long.  Some of her books are transition books which is like a puzzle piece you have to have before you can see the picture, Echo in the bone was this for me and the first time I read it I was not that happy with it but then I maybe expected too much, the second time I read Echo I liked it better but without echo you could not have had Written in my own hearts blood and this is a darn good book!  I loved that it was mostly about Jamie and Claire and I loved that the romance was full and pleasurable and I liked the sex scenes to be honest.  Diana always writes what it feels like, smells like, tastes like and looks like and it's easy to imagine your walking down a cobblestone street in 17th century America.  I think Diana Gabaldon is one of the best writers of her generation if not the best, I haven't found anyone better to be truthful.  So to sum it all up if you like historical fiction then you are going to love these but you must start from the first book and work your way up and for all of you lucky people I envy the fact that you get have the first time experience of Diana Gabaldon you lucky lucky people.

I'm done with the Outlander series.  Ms. Gabaldon is a great storyteller, but I get the feeling it's not about the story anymore, it's about cranking out yet another money-maker.  And her verbal tics are so annoying I can't get past them anymore.  Every single character flushes or blushes or reddens, even Sir John's black housekeeper.  Their mouths twitch and quirk, their lips compress, they're frequently amused, but they suppress their amusement, they snort, and they make lots of Scottish noises, whatever that means.  A peculiar bunch.  I'm tired of all of them.
I have loved this series and have read them multiple times. This is not her best and may be a good place to end the series, although I will miss the characters

It is not my favorite in the series. It is hard to say that after waiting four years for the installment. STILL, this series of books is my favorite. Diana Gabaldon breathes such life into the characters; they are like members of the family. I will be rereading, but more slowly.
I can't believe it took her this long to write this book. If u need to read it borrow it...don't pay money for this.

I have been literally holding my breath for this next installment - and I am afraid that I should have simply kept waiting ... At least then I would have been able to continue hoping for the best. I am a MAJOR fan of all of the previous Outlander books, Lord John books, and novellas - but this one was simply not good (and it is so hard for me to say that). The plot went absolutely nowhere and I believe lacked the edge-of-your-seat drama of the first books. I found myself thinking ""Really?!" numerous times during the course of this book. Don't get me wrong, Diana Gabaldon is an amazing writer who is capable of so much, but I was so disappointed with this one. The ending was especially frustrating for me ... no spoilers here ... just an overall sense of "Hmmm...OK...Well Then.... So Glad I waited 5 years for such a disappointing follow-up...

This was such a disappointing book that ended with yet another cliffhanger. I felt like it would never end, too many new characters that I just didn't care about. There would be chapters upon chapters without Jamie and Claire. I will not read the next book. It took way too long for this one to come out and wasn't worth the wait.
I don't know what I was hoping for but this fell way short of it.  It never seemed to get you excited like the rest of the series.

I love all the Outlander Books and also enjoyed reading this new book. However, it was frustrating to read because of the many different storylines attached to the different characters. I wanted more 'story' on the characters, what they were doing, how they got where they got, what happened to a character, so many questions unanswered. A book could be written on each group  of characters. The ending was also disappointing because it was such a surprise and there was no story development of the characters explaining the reasons they came to be where they were by the end of the book. The ending feels less like an ending and more like a pause in the story - which is disappointing,  particularly if there are not going to be any more books in the series.
I can't believe I waited so long for this book to come out and felt let down. It is probably one of my least favorite books.

I agree with the last review. The main part of the story is  OK but the author seems to ramble on about things that take away from the story totally and are in fact very boring. I skimmed through. I also think that she is going to overboard with the Jem and his sister bit. Most people I know are interested in Jamie and Clare not all the verbiage.  It seems she just wants to show off her research and add words instead of keeping to the main story line. Actually I thought the same about her 2 previous books. I know its difficult to keep a series going but after the 1st 3 books it has been going downhill to the point I hardly care anymore. Will probably still get the next book just to see what happens to Jamie and Clare.

this book is lame. lame. lame. maybe one of her characters would like to do something? hard to say. none of them seem compelled to do ANYTHING.  like watching an 18th Century bad reality show....(spoiler alert) they talk to each other.

I loved the first three or four "Outlander" books but I'm getting tired of them. In addition to the rape issue, is anyone besides me tired of the sheer "grossness" of the books? Yes, it's 1778 or whatever and standards of cleanliness were much different but how many times must we read about bloody clothes and snot and excrement? I'm not a squeamish person but I don't think it does anything for the stories.  Yes, I know; Claire is a doctor. Life was dirty in those times but to me, it just seems gratuitous.  Today I decided I'd had enough; William was hunting and stopped to pick up deer crap. REALLY?

I'm a passionate fan of the series up till now, and appreciate the time, effort and care that Ms. Gabaldon has put into each and every one of her books, but this one left me cold.  I do not choose to take my history lessons from my fictional novels, thank you.  I was interested in the characters, not the war.  I found it disjointed, lacking in the depth of character and plot that grabbed me in every other volume, and just overall a disappointment.  I suppose it is a bridge that had to be made to set up the next novel, but somehow I'm left feeling a bit used...

Unlike most fans I don't believe C&J; should be the absolute focus in the whole series. I am also different because, I don't read the books for the. "Romantic porn" I actually skip over most of them. To say the least this was the only book that had so much sexual coverage, that I've probably skipped half of the book.  Just so no one comes after me with torches and pitch forks, I am still a fan of the overall series. I just feel like there was a whole lot of nothing to the story line, mostly, it was dialogue from all previous books. Oh well, I still stick with terry brooks, so I will not give up on diana

I also discovered the Outlander series several years ago & read all thru "Breath of Snow.." Absolutely LOVE them!  When Echo came out--it also took me several weeks to finish--it was hard to get in to the story--way too much going on.  I was hoping "Written" would be less confusing.  Way too many characters doing way too many things-couldn't tell who was doing what (would have helped to have a character summary at the beginning to catch me up on who was who!).  It did drone on and on and on-I kept skipping ahead and don't think I missed anything.  Not near enough parts with Jamie & Claire and Bree & Roger.  Only reason I gave it 3 stars was the ending-won't spoil it.  I probably won't purchase the next one--I'll just read the last chapter in the bookstore & save me money!

Disappointed!!! I have just spent hours online trying to find out how this book ends so I don't actually have to read it!!! I have read this series several times and still love the first 5-6 books...but the last two books, not so much. If you are having trouble falling asleep at night, get this book, it works great!!!
Very disappointing.  Could not get beyond 200 pages.  It seems like she was trying to capitalize on popularity of tv series.

Lord it was bad…can't even imagine how it made the NY Bestseller list…guess folks were desperate to continue the saga & the author has her readers hooked.  I read the first 3 quite some time ago and I think there have been 3 more plus the current one. Also the books are now the base for a tv series on Starz called Outlander.  The main character, Claire, is a doctor so the author throws down or rather sprinkles liberally  medical situations from the 1700's, quite graphic raunchy sex scenes, time travel, Scottish Highlander tales, etc. I've never skimmed so many pages in any book…maybe not a good one for the Kindle either…don't ask me why I plugged through it. I guess I just kept hoping for a good part. Amazon give it 4 1/2 stars…go figure.

As the last book in a long series, I'm obviously a fan to the finish.  That being said, I think Gabaldon rushed the wrap up as far as some of the main characters.  I don't want to be a spoiler, but the author did such a good job developing certain characters in earlier books, it is surprising to me that the last book of the series puts some to rest with so few words.

I love this series but I was a wee bit disappointed by this book.  After waiting so long for it to be released, I don't feel like it really delivered.  I'm pretty bummed that I'll have to now wait possibly another 2-4 years for the next installment.  In the other books, I literally couldn't put them down.  The stories captured my attention from the start but I had a hard time actually picking this one up to continue reading.

Maybe it's because I read this on my iPad rather than holding a "real" book in my hands, but this novel felt less substantial (figuratively as well as literally) than others in this series. There were quite a few scenes that I really enjoyed but, on the whole, it felt like the only real purpose of this volume was to get us to the end ( which I won't reveal in case you haven't read it yet; although I'm guessing anyone who follows the series can guess that end even before starting the book). It was a long wait for this one, a nice but somewhat unsatisfying read and now, I suspect, a long wait for the next one.

Like many others, I am fascinated by these characters. An observation - I won't say criticism as Gabaldon is the best-selling author, not me - is that most of the books after the first two lack tight editing. They tend to wander around and fall down too many rabbit holes. Doesn't stop me reading, however, and I look forward to #9, God help me.

I hate to give one of these books anything less than 5 stars, but I just couldn't get into this volume in the series. I felt there were to many characters being followed, and very little advancement of plot for that reason. I'd like to see a lot of people relegated to minor character status and the focus brought back to the core Fraser family.

As a faithful follower of the series for 18 years I am sad to say this was sort of disappointing, especially after such a very long wait.  However compared to other novels out there this is so far superior to most modern historical fiction I hate to rate it low but compared to the author's earlier works I'd rate this the lowest of the series.

The series needs to end here. Some characters are just thrown into the book needlessly such as Jane & Fanny.  There seems to several areas of disjointedness and unnecessary explanations, since things happening earlier in the book shouldn't have to be explained. Was a disappointment. Is the author using others to write her books?
I am so sorry to have to give this rating. Unfortunately, that is what it earned. This is my favorite book series EVER. Until this book.

Disappointed in this book, I felt very cheated with the result of all those pages, seemed to be how long can we drag this story along, I feel that the story line could have been completed in half the number of pages, which is such a shame as I have enjoyed every book so far... we now have so many stories lines, and little seemed to be happen to any of them in this latest book.  I do hope the next installment starts heading to find some closure.

I was so very disappointed in the ending of this book.  With all the detail the author used for so much of everything else, she completely left out the part of Briana, Roger and their family's last trip.  I kept flipping pages in my Kindle, eager to get back to them only to have it just end with a very few lines.  It was so very anti-climatic.
