It makes me want to make up my own story to fill in the gaps.

Inconsistencies. The biggest is how did Roger and Brianna get to North Carolina and arrive in the correct period?  Last time we heard from them they were in Scotland with Jamie's father.  Was Ben really dead and did he have a wife and son?  What happened to William?  What happened to Rob Cameron and his cronies?  I was very disappointed with this book. I am ready for the series to end.

Another amazing book by Diana Gabaldon, but not quite as exciting, or involved with the characters from her previous books; many of whom we, as readers, had gotten to know so very well. This book definitely captures the history and events of the time (mostly in the 1700's), and indirectly or directly involves many well-known and historical heroes (e.g.,George Washington). The story seems to heavily focus on the history, which, indeed, has importance, but, unfortunately, therefore, seems to stray away from the intended storyline; so much so, that at times, I felt like I was reading a history book, rather than historical fiction with great characters. The author's shift and transition from historical information, to the characters, and then back again, was often not a smooth one, and was perplexing, to me, the reader. And, the introduction of several new characters, including some detailed information on the Quakers of that time, continued to dilute and minimize the other characters. As it is, the reader has a job recalling the many characters from her previous books, and how they relate to the current story, so the addition of so many new characters, becomes a task for the reader. Also, I found some outlandish and sensational story lines within the book which, I felt, took away from the story, instead of enhancing it.  For instance, the storyline involving Brianna, her son and daughter, in the 20th century, was so far-fetched that I almost put the book down, but on the other hand, Brianna's husband Roger, who had passed through the stones into the 1700's, seemed more "true" to the author's original style of writing.  Although I will always be a devoted fan of Diana Galbaldon, and I most definitely have loved her past books, I feel that she has strayed from her original successful style and therefore, this, for me, has changed my overall interest, and excitement for future books.

Confusing early in the story. Lagged along the way. Finally improved at the end. Too many characters interacting with little or no history reviews. It had been too long since the last book, and couldn't remember all the back stories.  It is time to end this series.

Oh dear.......I found this book to be disjointed, too many competing story lines, characters who did nothing for the story and whom I cared naught for, and soft porn which was pointless. It was a long read until we finally got to read continuously about Claire and Jamie's adventures without having to go off on, often, unimportant side stories!

Big disappointment. Diana, I love you. Please find an editor who can convince you to cut extraneous side plots (Sophronia and Jane as examples of many) and keep the plot and character development moving. This book is a plodder and I sure won't, for the first time ever, re-read it before the next one comes out.

I can't quite bring myself to give WiMOHB fewer stars although that would be a more honest ranking.  Like many readers, I've been hooked on the Outlander series, thoroughly immersed in the 18th century and caught up in the joys and tribulations of Jamie and Claire, their extended family and friends. This installment had its moments and I thank Ms. Galbadon for keeping us posted.  But... this book suffers from the same shortcomings that cropped up in all of the later books of the series, perhaps even more so - a serious lack of editing; too many contrived coincidences that stretch credulity and sexual violence used as a tension builder to move the story along(to the point it leaves you desensitized and bored with it). It also gets bogged down in excessive detail on Claire's practice of medicine.  The Brianna and Roger story was a yawner and didn't do anything for the rest of the book, so much so I skimmed through their chapters, not bothering with pages at a time. Who cares whether Roger and Brianna get to meet their ancestors? Brianna has been a two dimensional character throughout and that's a shame. I liked the development of Ian and John Grey. Would have liked to see and hear more from Jenny and see William grow out of his funk over his identity. Speaking of which, are he and all other Frasers completely immune to any molding from the people who raised them? There's no balance between nature and nurture which would have made William's inner struggle more realistic.  With that said, do I care enough to buy the next book and find out how mortality catches up to either Jamie and Claire? Probably not. I truly enjoyed the people (most of them), the exquisitely rendered settings, the history and Highland charm. It's time however to say goodbye to Outlander.  All good things ye ken, must come to an end.

Although I am a huge fan of Diana Gabaldon and the Outlander series, this was a terrible disappointment.  The story line was choppy, failing to complete the adventures of one set of characters without inserting only marginally related activities of another set of characters, before completing the original story line.  In past volumes of the series references to incidents or minor characters that reappear in another volume included sufficient background to jog the reader's memory. This happened rarely in "Written...Blood."  When a recollection appeared there was scarcely enough information to be of much help. The usual cliffhanger that keeps readers anxious for the next volume was not sufficiently or realistically concluded this time. Just when I thought it would finally happen, the book ended with excited characters running through the fields.  I was left wondering if that was all there was.  Then I realized that there wasn't enough of an ending to make me eager for another lengthy volume.  I have enjoyed the novellas that have been produced between the major novels. Unlike some reviewers, I saw these as similar to TV series spinoffs. There are characters worth knowing but not by taking away from Jamie and Claire as feature players. We can enjoy them in smaller settings. Perhaps therein lies the problem with "Written..." Did Diana get too used to the novellas that this major work ended up like a collection of unrelated novellas whose chapters were shuffled together via poor editing?  Only Diana and her team can answer that. Will I read other works that she produces?  Yes, but I won't spend time searching the internet to see when the next publication date is scheduled or look forward to an opportunity to preorder. Two stars only because of the few times that the old, brilliant style appeared and because I know what is possible. If this had been the first in the series I wouldn't have bothered to finish it.

Diana Gabaldon, or Herself, as many of her fans call her, has done it again.  First of all, the woman can flat our write, and she can spin a great tale, but mostly, she creates characters we love and care about, laugh and cry with, as if they were our own kin.  In this, book eight of the Outlander series, she picks up where she left off in book seven, with hero's Jamie Fraser's arrival back from the dead, and all it's import to the main characters of the piece, especially Lord John Grey, who has married Jamie's "widow"  Claire to keep her from being arrested as a traitor. We rejoin General Washington's troops, fresh from Valley Forge, at the Battle of Monmouth, with Claire in the midst of the battlefield surgery along with her friends, Dr. Denny Hunter and his sister Rachel.  Ian MacKenzie, Jamie and Claire's nephew, discovers his mother has not died in the shipwreck with his Uncle Jamie, and continues to court Rachel, while scouting for the Continental Army with his beloved dog, Rollo.  Meanwhile, Jamie and Claire's daughter, Bree, back in the 20th century, discovers that her son has not been kidnapped and taken to the other side, and must now deal with what to do about her husband, Roger, who, along with his ancestor, "Buck" MacKenzie, has gone through the portal at the standing stones, to find his son.  (If you have read the novella, A Leaf in the Wind at All Hallow's, one of your main questions concerning events in that will be answered in Roger's return visit.)  It's all there, and yes, it does go a little slowly at times, it's still great fun to read, to see our "friends" again, and to reflect on the choices they make and the events which lead them to the end of this particular part of their lives., and how they deal, or don't deal, with them. The ending chapter was particular satisfying for me:  "Hello the house!"  You'll understand when you've read it.  So, five stars for Written in My Own Heart's Blood, To repeat myself, Diana does it again, and I for one, thank her very much.

After waiting so long to learn what happened to Jamie and Claire in the Outlander series of books, I have to say that I am so disappointed with this latest offering that I could cry.  How on earth can someone who wrote the first absolutely fantastic books in the series churn out such a dreadfully boring offering like this?  I have never been so disappointed in my life. Sadly I have to advise potential readers to save their money - so very, very sad.

Like other reviewers, I feel that this book is the worst of the series. The book just drags on and appears to go nowhere. I had a hard time putting the first five books in the series down. Now, I have a hard time picking this one up to finish it. Great disappointment.

I had a lot of trouble getting through the first 10 pages.  I put the book down and figured I was just sleepy and would try again.  I still couldn't get through them.  I'm not sure I'll ever be able to get past that point in this book.  I am SO over these characters.

I have been a fan of this series for almost 20 years, waiting with baited breath for each book to come out. The first half of this book covers the course of approximately three weeks.  Good, alot of details.  The second half is choppy.  The last I would say maybe 5% of the book gives short answers as to what happens, but no detail as to how it happens.  (I am trying to write this without giving spoilers, so it might not make total sense, sorry about that)  Most of this story IS Clare and Jaime. So for those who want that...they will enjoy it.  For those of us who also enjoy William, Bree and Roger....let alone the other characters on the Ridge, you might be a bit disappointed.

Disappointing.  Too many extraneous plotlines going that add nothing to the story.  This feels like filler and seems a very cavalier treatment of a beloved (up to now) series.  I wouldn't recommend it.

I enjoyed this book and thought the prose was beautiful.  I love almost all the characters, and cannot wait to see what happens next in the story.  The military history  I have a few issues though - it was totally all over the place.  Within the 1770s storyline, there was too much back and forth between too many characters.  I would have rather there been separate books exploring various characters than have them all crammed into one book.  My main problem was too much William, and most of the book consisted of him being a total jerk, throwing a self-involved tantrum that basically lasted hundreds of pages - including multiple outbursts that I found pretty unforgivable - and his conflicts and rambling misadventures with runaway prostitutes were not interesting enough to warrant the amount of pages devoted to them.  I was also frustrated by the ongoing tensions between Jamie and Lord John, their friendship has always been one of my favorite parts of the series and their interactions were fairly disappointing, and I liked Jamie far less in this book than I ever have before.  I think that if she had done some novellas or spin-off series that were companions to this book, it would have been better in the long run.  That said, I really do like the book and love the series.

A long wait for a very disappointing and common novel. Had I not already been involved with the characters, I would have put the book down after the first hour. If there's another one in the works, I would hope Mrs. G would return to her roots
These books are becoming more burdensome to read. They plots drag on and this book in particular brought no resolution. I think it's time to start wrapping things up Diana.

I was VERY  disappointed in this book.  I felt it was very disjointed and hopped around a lot.  I have read the previous 7 books and enjoyed them very much.  This one should have started out with a synopsis since the books were written so far apart.

I couldn't wait, I preordered, and waited, and waited.  Finally it arrived, oh the wonderful feel of a new book, the glossy cover promising untold intriguing reading moments, secret tears I will shed, laughing out loud into an otherwise empty family room, embracing Claire for her caring medical attentions, etc. etc. It didn't happen.  I even forgot who Buck was. And now I am being introduced to the ensuing problems that Breanne faces in which I am really not that interested. Claire and Jamie have been my interests throughout the past 7 volumns. Ok, enough said. I am bored 150 pages in and peeking through the following several hundred pages, a lot of war-type scenarios about to unfold which I really don't care for. Maybe it is just time for me to finish the Outlander Series personally while the first volumes still hold a close second to Jean Auel's "The Clan of the Cave Bear"  (Earth's Children) Series.  Thank you, Diana. It was a tremendous amount of work and you have given much reading pleasure to millions of fans.

I was also a fan of the Outlander Series until this book.  It just seems to be filled with too many characters and plots that are hard too follow. Also, the whole charm of the Jaimie and Claire story seems to have become lost in this book. I don't think that I will be reading anymore books in the series.
Sending it back, the prevailing misogynistic themes just don't appeal to me  That attitude doesn't speak romance, some history perhaps, but not romance,

Where is th  rest of the book ?  Let me guess.  Part one of the last book in the series.  Then at Christmas you will come out with part two, soaking me another $30 for hard back and another fee for kindle edition  because I have to have both.  Do you really need money that bad?  So many ends left flying in the smoke.  End this already!

Diana Gabaldon writes a good story and does her research well. I've read all the books in this series, and consider Outlander the best. I had problems with this one. There are too many characters, too many plot threads, and I found myself skipping down the first paragraphs of each new chapter to find out who I was reading about, because there was no indication at the beginning. I was also taken aback by her characters acting out of character. She developed those characters. She knows them intimately. She should know what they will do, how they will react.. How did Brianna, who was a whiney, somewhat unlikable young woman, suddenly become the strong, self-reliant person w're seeing here?.And does anybody really believe for a moment, knowing Claire, that,when she thought Jamie dead, she would get drunk every day and then marry Lord John Grey? No. Claire has thought Jamie dead before and she didn't react this way. .The Claire we all know would have gone back through the stones to Brianna, Jem and Mandy. That might not have served Diana's plotline, but you can't twist the character's responses into something so unbelievable simply to mold them into your plotline.

Should have believed the negative reviews. I was hoping they were wrong.  Diana got lost on this one and lost me. Too long. Too confusing. I would have given it less than one star if I had the option. Waste of my time. Sorry Diana. I think your editor was snoozing.
Awful!
Totally disappointed.  Too many sub stories and not enough conclusion.  I have read all the books in the series and this left me angry that the ending was so worthless.
Certainly did not live up to the rest of the series of books. Very disjointed and very frustrating reading!! Obviously written to set up next book, but after year of waiting was an anticlimax

Was Ms. Gabaldon paid by the word for this book?  Is she employing so many researchers that the national economy would suffer if she did her own research?  Did she farm out the various aspects of this book to a small corps of writers then compile it into one 825 page many-plotted, bloated story? Why does she find it necessary to write a tome when a book would serve us all so much better? Has success, as it too often does, ruined a good author? These are the questions of a fan who loves Gabaldon's writing and her series, but is beginning to question why.  I literally had to slog through parts one and two and didn't get to the "real" Diana Gabaldon, adored authoress, until part three. Even then some of the sentences were overlong and disjointed.  We want to stay with you Diana, really we do. Can you make it a little easier for us to do that?
The book is formulaic. The author uses the same bag of tricks over and over. I guess my honey moon with Outlander is also over.
My least favorite of all her books. It was too long between book 7 and this one.  The last half was better than the first.
Book was way too long with uninteresting stuff in it. Half the pages, tighter writing would have made all the difference.
Long awaited and well worth the wait!  Thank you Diana Gabaldon, it's another GREAT read and haven't put it down yet...what to do when I am done though in a day or two???
This book was rather choppy with no smooth transitions.  I enjoyed her other books in the series, but not so this one.
Like many series , it is becoming predictable and formulaic. Still an OK read. Maybe part of the ugh factor had to do with anticipation.
More of the same leaving not only the door, but all of the windows, wide open for the next book. A disappointment.

Disjointed, skimpy on big events for Jamie and Claire, battle scenes tedious and confusing and interminable travel with military baggage chains.  Spoiler alert: Completely omits mention of repair of Mandy's heart. Gabaldon writes with mastery in several of her other books but this one feels phoned in. If she's going to keep using Scots Gaelic, I wish she'd bother to check all the phrases with her Gaelic experts, "mo" and vocative case cause lenition.

Have loved this series for a long time, but find I can't even finish the book, it's so boring. So I went to the reviews to find out if I'm. way off base in feeling so bored, bored, bored. What a comfort it's been reading the other 1-star reviews, which are much more entertaining to read than the book, sadly. Way too many minor characters to keep track of, way too many detailed descriptions of ho-hum everyday life, way too little plot or insight into characters' emotions. I'm okay with books centered on either character, inner life, or plot, but this book seems centered on DESCRIPTION and really needs some heavy editing and most of all, focus. There's no focus, and therefore little heart or story or interest. Will probably not finish this book.

As I read all eight of the novels in the OUTLANDER series, I sometimes wondered if Ms. Gabaldon was paid by the word or if she had an editor who did nothing.  If she enjoyed writing this series, always expanding the geographical and personnel scope, good for her.  I thought that the novels were way too long, and I really trudged through this last novel.  Time travel is major to the overall story, as is the fact that the main character was a nurse then surgeon in the 1960s before traveling back in time and being a female doctor in the mid-1770s..  This last novel takes place during the Revolutionary War with the added feature that the main character knows what will happen (and to whom) and who will win the war.  Enough already.

I waited a long time for this book, along with many others. At first I was enjoying returning to the story. Then I realized it was never going to end. More characters added, more filler items, more surgical stories, all leading no where. Sex and more sex. Nothing gets resolved, and nothing gets answered. How did Brianna get from the stones to Lallybroch with two small children. Why was Roger's father introduced but then not sent in the right direction through the stones, and is this the only reason the timing was off. How did they get to the Ridge, in the right time, across the ocean from where they started. Who are the enemies plotting against the families. Why does no conversation between William and Jaime ever end with William learning the truth about who Jaime really is. It is all so pointless because not one thing is ever resolved. 800+ pages and all for what?  To read one more story about war and aging characters giving up everything AGAIN, and another fire, and so on. I probably will read the next book, but at this point, when will it ever end? DG certainly had ample opportunity to wrap it all up, 600 pages cold have been devoted to the stories we all wanted to have wrapped up. But no. Not this round.

I still like the first 3 books in the Outlander series best. However, book 8 is just as detailed, complicated, full of surprise events and odd people showing up. It's exciting to imagine the American Revolution from the inside out too and some famous historical people are in this book. I recommend "Heart's Blood" to all Outlander fans, to fans of historical novels, time slip novels and to fans of colonial American history. Once again, Claire Fraser is up to her elbows in blood and guts, working medical marvels under very rustic conditions. Jamie is scowling and storming around, trying to keep his family safe, as he is drawn in to the war. Guess who he meets and how he serves in this war!  Read the book!

I love the Outlander series. No one creates a sense of historical place like Diana Gabaldon, her character development is top-notch, and her plots are fizzy "outlandish" fun. Unfortunately, there was a lot of place in this latest installment but not much else. It has detailed history, a few wild coincidences, and a checklist of character activity. Especially after the tedium of "Echo," I think I'm done with this series; there are better sources for history and plenty of romance plots that make more sense. Fortunately, this book ends in a way that I can live with, and I know the outcome of the war, so I'm satisfied to walk away now.

What's not to love about Diana Gabaldon? She is simply the best author ever. Other books are entertaining, but until you read a Diana Gabaldon story you don't realize how a writer can help you to truly like and care for the characters. That is why there is such a huge fan following-her characters become friends. The colorful descriptive language makes you truly feel like you are there like a fly on the wall. Who hasn't said at least once in their life that they wish they could be a "fly on the wall", well, this is your chance. Definitely read the main books (there are multiple shorter books and stories too) in the order they were written.

I felt totally out of sorts after I finished reading the 7th book of Outlander.  I hung on every word Diana Gabaldon wrote.  She writes so well that I kinda felt transported myself.  I honestly didn't feel like reading anything else afterwards.  However, (the inevitable however) Heart's Blood did not capture my imagination as the previous stories did.  Whereas I read the former novels until I could read no more, it was different with Heart's Blood from which I took many breaks.  Perhaps it was the length of time between the series?  I'm not saying Heart's Blood was not readable - it was.  Just not as taken as I was with the others.

Let me start by saying that I was very late in coming to this series. I loved being able to read the first seven books back-to-back and simply fell in love with both the characters and their stories. I was overjoyed to find that the latest book was released just as I was ready to read it.  With the other ones still so fresh in my mind, I can easily say that this title is the weak link in the series. Way too many new characters introduced that crowded out those I actually wanted to read about. At the end of this book, I still don't care about Hal, yet the Grey storyline took up a large part of this book. I agree with the other reviews I've read, the author needs to get back to the basics of what made this series so popular.

As many others have stated this book is redundant and unsatisfying . The multiple rapes the bringing up of the past... It was all very random and there were a lot of elements that were brought up for no reason it seemed and then just ended with no  explantation! I love her books but after the first two or three it just started to kind of unravel and be rather weird. After being left hanging in the last book I was really looking forward to this one although now I wish I hadn't read it! Before I would reread the books but now I have a bad taste in my mouth and I don't think I'll pick them up again unfortunately.
I asume her editor was on a leave of absence for this book? If there was an editor present, shame on them.

I found this to be the least interesting and most disjointed of the books in this generally marvellous series. I had trouble keeping characters and places straight, there were too many characters from the Lord John books (which I have no interest in reading),and when I finished I had a number of plot questions, unexplained events, like why Roger went through the stones and ended up in an earlier period than usual (and met his own father there???); and how Brianna and he and the kids managed to get back to the time period inhabited by Jamie and Claire. Too many things left unexplained. Not the best one.

The final chapter in the Outlander series, the author takes a convoluted pathway to tie up the lose ends. The characters are introduced at times, without a purpose in mind for them. I enjoy the relationship of Claire and Jamie, even though she's got to be pushing 60, but this time we get in bed with Ian and Rachel and the Hunters. Too much voyeurism for me. How did Roger and Brianna get to the right decade at the end of the book? What became of William, and wasn't his attachment to the prostitute, Jane, kind of random? Oh well, at least the monkey is off my back until she writes another book.

Waited far too long for this to come out. For much of the book, I was wondering why this part and that part were thrown in because they had absolutely nothing to do with the plot...and then there were very plot related incidents that were just swept over, and we were left to try and fill in the gaps. I have thoroughly enjoyed the seven previous books in the series, but was definitely not pleased with this one. Possibly Diana Gabaldon was too involved with the mini series that was coming out to put her full attention to this book in the series. By the way, the TV show is fantastic!

If this had been her first in the series, there wouldn't have been a second. Tossed off in her spare time & it shows. Answers what was left hanging in her last novel in the series, the rest is filler. Sex & the American Revolution. Every character when not on the battlefield is unlacing stays. Leather laced stays, knotted laced stays. More panting than in a kennel. Even repeats her rape scene in more complete detail in a flashback filler. Kills off two regulars with a ho hum attitude. An  insult to her fans, author was too busy with her other efforts to put any real story in this one. You won't be panting to read the next.

Starting to feel like we're dragging a bit. I LOVE the characters, even many of the side ones and J&C;'s progeny, however, all stories must come to an end. I'm getting about ready for this one to end, before I start to feel stagnant and bored as many of the other readers seem to have. We're beginning to see a pattern of the same kind of protagonism over and over and new characters seem much like previously seen characters. I'm ready to see the family finally settle on the Ridge or back at the Broch and get their much earned happily ever after. (Note i would give this 3.5 stars if i could. I still find it better than a 3 but really not quite a 4)

I'll keep it short and sweet.  I love DG..and her Outlander Series, however I'm struggling with this book.  I skipped through and read the Brianna story line completely enthralled, because she kept skipping back and forth between Bri and Claire to often...It was giving me a headache.  Now I struggle with all the military overtures in the line of Jamie and Claire.  I will make it through eventually, but I think the story is getting drawn out for page length, and that is unnecessary.  600 pages is as good as 800 if it captures the reader.

It's been a long five years since read Gabaldon's last book, but it doesn't take long to fall back into the world of Jamie and Claire... plus all the other people who've entered the picture since this series began. It's an historical fantasy time traveling adventure, to be sure- but at its heart It's probably the most complex, beautiful  love story you'll ever read. VERY happy they're starting to make it into a TV series, on STARZ, and doing a beautiful job of casting and staying truce to the nuances.

I am a huge fan of this series, but I have to say after the long wait for this book I was a little disappointed. I t was still a good book, and I was thrilled to read abut what was happening in the lives of the characters, but it didn't seem quite up to the caliber of the previous books. I couldn't write even one book, not to mention the volume of wonderful writing Gabaldon does. So I will be waiting for the next in the series, since the ending of this one was the most exciting part!

I love Diana Gabaldon and I love this series.  I was so excited when this one finally came out but was disappointed in the end.  I felt like nothing was accomplished, not like some of her other books where things happen, time passes and issues are resolved.  This one left me feeling dissatisfied, I feel like she has to many story lines happening to really devote good quality time to them all.  That being said I still love the series and will most definitely be reading the next book.

It was okay. I really liked the first two novels the best. The third was pretty good also. I do have to say I started in August with the first novel Outlander, and then finished all the books in the series one right after another. I simply couldn't put them down.  I couldn't get enough of Claire and Jamie. I did skip the fiery cross though, because I read that it had too much of the daughter and her husband in it and I find them boring. However, overall I really like this series.

Definitely not the best in the series. Slogging through 822 repetitive pages, jumping character to character (many of whom I could care less about), from one improbable coincidence to another, made me realize just how ready I am for this series to end. Even the multiple sexual romps placed strategically throughout failed to hold my attention. If it weren't for my 23 year investment in Jamie & Claire, I'd never have finished this one.  Probably should have just read the summary.
Unfortunately a good writer is dragging out a script for a soap opera.

I was very disappointed with  book 8. having devoured all the others I was looking forward to see how the series ended instead it just stops. Its like she got tired of writing. so many questions and issues remain unresolved even if it had been something as simple as " he learn to live with it" or "decided it wasn't worth pursuing" that would have helped, but no. It just ended. Unless I am wrong, and there is a volume 9: in conclusion. Very disappointing.

I've read the previous books in this series.  Like many other reviewers, I was enchanted by the first novel, quite interested in the second, and rather bored by the subsequent novels.  The historical context remains interesting, but the plots are fairly predictable.  The elements of cutesiness, snappy, trite banter, and implausible situations is - for me - overwhelming any sustained interest in the novels. I'm just continuing to read these books for old times' sake...

Outlander, the first book in this series, is my favorite book ever.  I introduced this series to family and friends, gave copies of Outlander as gifts, and I have the first part of the TV series on my DVR.  I am a FAN!  However, this book is so full of side stories and boring extra characters, I skimmed a lot of it.  The ending was wonderful and got back to the elements of what made this series so great.  It's too bad the whole book wasn't the same.

I have been a huge fan of Outlander for years. The last book was poorly written, but this one is literally unreadable. Diana, just stop. No one cares about Lord John or William. Just finish the darn series and be done. I'm 17% of the way in to whatever this painful installment is called, and I can't finish due to the exponential number of characters and extremely poor plot. Diana, are you even trying anymore? Five years (or whatever it has been) in development for this? Readers: stop before Snow and Ashes. Give yourself hours of your life back.

It was good to revisit with Claire and Jamie but the story seemed repetitive of prior ones. War, house burns down, moving from place to place. Then there were pages given to William whose story was no story so I skipped over all his parts. All in all I found it boring. I never read the last book before this one because of reviews similar to this and found it didn't matter. Hard to say if I will read the next one. Took me 3 months to finish it.

It 's hard to believe the adventure of Claire & Jaime et al is really over. I have loved these stories as much as I loved the Jean Auel Earth' s Children series so many years ago. I can't help but compare the talent of these two insightful storytellers. The worlds of these characters are so rich they will stay with me forever. That being said, I did find the pace of this story somewhat erratic and the ending abrupt. But I enjoyed every word.

If you are this far in the series, you're going to read it anyway. But it won't be your favorite. At multiple times through the book, this reader is keeping track of three plot lines. They aren't cohesive at all. If Gabaldon is going to keep writing about this enormous family tree of characters, she should branch off into separate series. Also, some parts were engaging, but overall I thought it dragged a bit.

First let me say I have read the first seven books and have only the highest praise for them. This eighth one is the most disjointed, boring book I have read in a while. This is not to mention the repetition that is starting to show. I just don't see a five star rating in this book. I think the author needs to re-read some of her past novels if she wants to continue this storyline. If not this would be a great place to end it.

Just spent the last two days reading this straight through. Some parts of it drag a bit - I know that battle of the Revolutionary War was the longest one, but man, it really feels it reading it -- and we get a lot of scenes that we've been waiting for for a while (I won't spoil them). Feels like everything is in place for the last book to wrap up the final loose ends, and of course we're all waiting for that already. :)

I loved and have re-read the first three books of the series.  With each successive book, I enjoyed them less and less, although I always finished them.  I made it 100 pages in this one and realized I was no longer interested in the characters.  The plot lines are increasingly unbelievable and unnecessarily violent.  Must we really have kidnapping of an innocent child - again?

I love this series, but this latest is not up to Diana's previous efforts.  It moves very slow and there are very few OMG moments.  With all the other books in the series I couldn't put the book down.  With this, I got bored and only continued to read it hoping for something BIG to happen.  She did leave it open at the end for another.  I'll probably read it, because I love the characters.  Just need more of a story with the next one.

It was good and had the fascinating details you love from Diane.  However this was a building up book to a story we all have been waiting on....will Briana and family ever return to Claire or vice versa and why?  You read through a whole book to get to the real story and it ends!  I think you could actually skip this book and start at the next book with very little lost.

Too many characters/stories are weakening the book overall.  The big wait for this book has made me forget why I care about any of the other characters or who they are.  Still love Claire and Jamie.  Wish we could get back to the core not the "side bar" stories occurring on the periphery.  I've truly enjoyed the earlier books.  But, I find myself putting this book down quite a bit.

It's time for Gabaldon to wrap up this series. There were story lines in this novel that did little to nothing to advance the plot. As for the Grey family: Frankly, Diana, I don't give a damn. I will always love the Jamie/Claire relationship and adore Ian/Rachel. I am happy to see everyone back on the Ridge but it is time to end. The stones as a revolving door is getting ridiculous.

I enjoyed the story, but I would have liked to have heard more re Brie, and Roger and their children.  A good bit involved them at the beginning with very little tie in until the end.  I thought adding them to the last few pages of the book was an afterthought and not well planned.  By the end of the book I was very bored with the endless detail of the Battle of Monmouth.

That is my complaint. I read slowly, took breaks, and tried to drag out the process of reading a book that I waited so long for but finished it anyway. I hope the story continues. We all need a little Jamie and Claire.

Diana has, once again, created a marvelously well-rounded book with fascinating characters and great plot.  My only quibble is that she has a hard time describing Claire as she grows older.  After all, Claire was 27 when she first came through the stones in 1743 and now its 1778.

A disappointing read considering her previous novels. The only part that held my interest was the Roger/Brianna story line which gets dropped in the middle of the novel. The Jamie/Claire story line is a regurgitation from previous books. I've truly enjoyed the Outlander series up to this book; sad, but I doubt I'll read another if it's written.

I have been reading this series for years and was really looking forward to this one.  After finishing it I must say  I felt a little let down.  It was an okay read  and I liked catching up on all the  characters' lives but  it didn't  hold my interest.  One thing I love about Diana Gagaldon's books is their length but this one dragged for me.

Very disjointed , chapters introducing characters with no tie-in to the story. There are some great beginnings, but little to no follow through. And there's the rape deal, seems every female character past and present has been raped. just not any where near the previous books. But the good news is that I no longer care if she takes five years to write another.

When I finished this book, I thought, "That's it? Really?" I felt rushed through some parts and dragged through others. Lots of back- & forth-ing. Several things weren't explained fully--like how did Roger & Bree find each other again, how did Jamie get Claire back to Philly after she was shot--she couldn't recover that fast!

Up till now I have really enjoyed this series of books. All of them including this one are very well written. It's just that I was disappointed by the content of this one. It was a little too soap opera for my tastes.  Though I will continue to look for other publications by this author, I have to say I was disappointed.

As with all sagas, once you begin, you get caught up in the story and often have to wait too long  for the continuation. This one was the weakest historically. The characters become almost super human. They manage to have considerably active sex lives under nearly impossible circumstances. Maybe too much of a good thing?

I was so looking forward to this book but after reading it, I am so disappointed!  This book waffles on about the wars in America in the 1770's, going into so much detail about insignificant things and giving puffed up descriptions of people and events just to fill the pages.  I think it's time to let the series go.

I enjoy stories with long term arcs, characters that grow & change over time but this latest segment is awful. Disjointed,too many unfinished plotlines, ridiculous twists & no real conclusions. It is a string of short stories bound together in the guise of a "complete" book. I couldn't wait for it to end.

Not nearly enough Jamie and Claire and way to much off in other directions... I have all of her books and was really looking forward to this one.  To me, it seemed like she was using sub-plots to make it a BIG book without the heart of the other books.  Won't wait for another; this one was too disappointing.

Is it just me or does each installment seem to get more action packed, flowing over with characters, and yet less "meaty".  I am not disappointed but frustrated that my expectations run way faster than the author can, wants, or should be pumping out material in this series.

I felt Diana skipped around a lot in this book, was a little hard to follow at times.  Did not like the ending, seemed liked it dropped into space.  It was not as captivating as her other Outlander books but I am hoping she is writing book 9.  I have enjoyed this series very much.

Had a difficult time getting into this one.  It seemed to jump around a lot, the writing wasn't as crisp, and the plot not as well developed as with past books.  Frankly, I do not care that much about many of the characters any more.  They've become rather stale and unbelievable.

While there is a lot of historical action, I didn't feel as though it melded with the chief characters as in prior novels.  Things improved over time, but felt myself losing interest.  At the end, I was hoping it would continue, but alas...,,,Not up to Gabaldon's usual standard.

The first four books were good reading. The only reason I finished " Written in my Own Hearts Blood" is that I bought it on my Kindle. The characters seem mundane and boring. I think this can happen with a series. It's hard to keep the books exciting and interesting.

Have waited so long for this to come out, was very disappointed. The last few books are more about history and have deviated from the actual story regarding the Frasers which we know and love. On the up side this volume wasn't as long, would still rather have quality than quantity

After reading the previous 7 books I found repeating the back story from the previous books very repetitive and  unnecessary. The author could have shortened the book significantly making it more enjoyable to read.  It is unlikely that I will purchase the next book.

I felt she left so many unanswered questions in this book, not just at the end but all thru the book. the love scenes were more crude than the way she always described love scenes before. like she was competing with 50 Shades of Gray, 2 others in my book group agreed.

Since I've arrived at book 7, I'm obviously a fan. And admittedly not all books in this series have been home runs, but this has been a chore to get through. Perhaps it's time for Diana to break down and outline her plots. Has success spoiled Diana? We`'ll see.

for me, it dragged on a bit; too much war, fighting, and details i did not care about re john grey and his family…  ending makes it obvious another book is coming, or gabaldon just gave up!  either way, not the storyline with jamie and claire i was hoping for

Not as good as the other books in the series. Somewhat predictable. Certainly not worth a 4 year wait. It seems like she is gearing toward the end of the series. If there wasn't a next book it would be ok since it didn't end with a cliffhanger or unanswered questions.

I got the feeling she was trying to tie up loose ends but at the same time introducing hew situations which to me didn't have successful conclusions or any conclusions. I get the impression this is her last book of this series. To me it was the weakest.

Disappointed with this one. I have read all Diana's book, but this one seems to be put together haphazardly. Lots of areas of boredom and the story line does not flow very well. This was an electronic download and received in immediately after purchase.

I have thoroughly enjoyed all eight of her books. They are, historical, romantic and adventuresome. I feel it really does give me some insight into what it was like to live back in that era. I just wish she'd write a ninth novel to the Outlander series

Having read all the Outlander series, I think I kind of drifted off after the Drums of Autumn (which I did like, twas the next book that lost me.) This one didn't do it for me either. I'd rather re-read the early books thanks all the same Diana.

Finish reading the book but still with lots of unanswered questions. At one point had to go back to make sure I didn't skip a chapter. Would have rather she took her time a give more details as in her past books. Hope there's another book coming!

Doesn't have the depth of emotion or descriptive narrative of the earlier books.  Story lines "jump and run" too quickly between short chapters; difficult to keep up at times. As an avid fan of the series this book was disappointing.
worst book Diana has ever written.

Kind of lost it's "punch", maybe because we waited so long.  They say anticipation is nine tenths of  a pleasure, well, maybe this was the case.  It seemed slow, like it was winding down the series.  Just one person's opinion!

Now I've read the entire series and though it was interesting I can't say it was a great work of literature.  It was entertaining, and the characters interesting, but I think the ending was rather predictable and not engaging.

I love this book.  Since this is the last book in the series for the time being, I savored ever single word.  Jamie and Claire and their extended family feel like family members to me.  I'm longing for the story to continue.

Another spectacular historical fiction novel from Gabaldon.  If you've read her previous books this one is a must read. following Jamie, Claire and their family through the American revolution. It can be a real eye opener!
Not as good as her other books,

I love this book, however it's been so long since I read the last one that I can't remember some of the lesser characters and plot lines. I will have to dust off the book from 2009 to see if it helps refresh my memory.

I have read the complete series and this one left me with mixed feelings. I expected a story with a faster pace. I enjoyed it but I think it was more of the same... too much war/fighting and very gruesome descriptions.

I'm glad it's her last book of Jamie and Claire as not much more could of happened to to anyone. Book could've been half the size. Story line was too drug out. Also didn't need to learn so much regarding surgeries.

Diana Gabaldon continues to amaze me with her attention to detail and inclusion of interesting historical footnotes.  I couldn't put the book down once I had started reading it and I'm always sad when I finish one!

Too much Revolutionary War NOT ENOUGH of the characters we love so much! It wasn't til the end of the book that I finally got involved again.  I'm done, sorry to say.  I think Diana lost her passion for the books.

Was hoping for a read that kept my interest, and my attention drawn to the story. However, this book was uninteresting &  took me over a month and a half to finish. Ugh... bummed that this story is dragging.

I was surprised that it held my interest all the way through.  I have either read or listened to all of the previous books in this series and enjoyed this.  Of course I will be looking forward to the next one

I was really disappointed in this book, especially as it is the last in the series.  Too much of the war and not enough about the characters. Doesn't tell us how Brianna and Roger found each other again, etc.

I am in love with this series. Everyone should read it. Gabaldon writes of married love with such care and compassion. It is never easy and she tells the hearty and soul of it. Don't miss any of these books.

I was totally disappointed in this book.  In my opinion it did not measure up to the previous books at all.  It didn't leave me with the feeling of excitement either in the story line or the characters.

I loved this series, but this book didn't quite live up to the earlier books.  If it had been the first book of the series, I wouldn't have read all the rest.  After such a long wait, I am disappointed.
Always love to be in the world of Jaime and Claire.  The beginning of the book was all over the place with many characters.  Once I got into it I started to enjoy it.  Sorry it had to come to an end.
Diana spent too much time with stories and details on non key characters. I have loved the series but the publishers need to know its okay for the author to write shorter books with less fillers.

I cannot wait for the next one. I love Jamie and Claire. Their love and life, it is all every person would want. I know it is not easy, but life is not easy. I have to say that this like the previous one is similar to the first three books that I love. I did not like the three in between that much. So, Jamie is back and is faced with the fact that John had carnal knowledge of Claire and is really not too happy about it. He punches John and tries to do any possible damage, but also appreciates the fact that his friend was honest with him. And finally when he meets with Claire and they are together, he listens, he does not like it, but he is wiling to listen and understand. His love is stronger than that and besides Claire did think he was dead and it almost killed her. At the same time, Bree and Roger with Jem and Mandy are in Lallybroch facing their own problems. Jem is kidnapped and Roger goes through the stones to rescue him, but he ends up in 1739 meeting Brian and young Dougal. I liked that. There are many stories, the most important is the story of Claire and Jamie, but I enjoyed William's, John's, Ian's and the fact that Jenny was with them. A lot of things happened. William struggles with the fact he was not who he thought he was, but...the end is pretty much what I thought it would be. Claire and Jamie see a couple with two kids who ....
Great reading, but too many things left untold.  What happened to some of the characters?  It was like the author just got tired of the whole thing and wanted to end it and get it over with.
Book 8 was a much slower read than the previous seven. I was hoping that Gabaldon would wrap up the saga, but she has another in the works. I guess I'll have to wait another four years.
I have loved the Outlander series since the beginning.  But the last two books, in my opinion, have stretched out what little story there is with a lot of unnecessary medical details.
Another fabulous read!  I do hope that Ms Gabaldon is working on the next book and that it will be out soon!  As with all of her books, I had a really difficult time putting it down.
I didn't find it as engaging as the earlier books in the series.  I could see that she was trying to tie everything together but it seemed like the sub-plots were all over the place.
I have loved this series until the last two. The last was so inconsistent with the previous ones it felt as if someone else had written it. This one is just boring. So disappointing.
Story lines were all over the place, just didn't think it was as good as the ones before. For a book this big you would expect the story lines too be moved forward a little more

There are many excellent reviews here in the 3 star category that say all the things I was thinking - so unlike the novel's author *ahem* I see no need for pointless repetition! When I got to the end of this book, I said to my friend "Well the book has stopped." Not so much "concluded" or even "ended"...but stopped. Some of the newer characters are interesting and compelling - but others are too flat to get me very caught-up in their trials and tribulations. What SHOULD have been a heart-rending scene with a minor character towards the end left me a bit glad it was over!  This installment wandered from character to character without wrapping up really ANY of the various subplots, and left many questions unanswered without creating a gripping enough tension to keep me eager to find out how they are resolved. In fact, I have a feeling the next book will meander through the same scenarios without resolving them, AGAIN. But I will probably still buy it, because (and hence the 3 stars) Outlander was brilliant and one of my favourite books ever, Claire and Jamie  are still beloved characters, and I do still care enough to see how it all turns out.  I just hope that a conclusion is forthcoming - and more satisfying than the last 2 books have been!
A return to form after some low points in several of the previous books. Interesting twists but much easier to follow the characters and plot lines without confusion. I enjoyed it!
An eagerly awaited book as I really like the series.  However, with this one, I thought the author got rather bogged down in the war section seemingly just to make the book longer.
Lots of history. Felt like part of this family. Loved Claire and her medical knowledge and how she brought that with her back to the 1700's. Read and enjoyed the entire series.
I think she should end the series. It ends as badly as the last one. How did Roger and Bree get 200 yrs from Scotland to America? I suppose she expects to write another sequel.

What is there not to love about Diana Gabaldon's books?  The only bad thing I can say is that you come to the end of the book and have to wait for Ms. Gabaldon to write another.  With so much research going into her books and the fact that "The Outlander" is now on Starz, I would assume it will take a while to write another.  In this last book, Claire's son-in-law plays a larger part as he's forced to go back through the stones because he and Bree, Claire and Jamie's daughter and Roger's wife, think that Jem, their son has been kidnapped and taken back to the 18th century.  Going with him is his great-great-great grandfather, who mistakenly went through the stones into the 20th century, landing at Lallybroch.  Of course, there's the story of Claire and Jamie, Ian, Jamie's nephew and many others.  Some who are historical.figures, lots of battles, action, love and much more.  This book, as with the ones before it. have something for everyone and if you're careful, you can try to make the book last just a little bit longer because coming to the end is so heart-breaking and you wonder how you will ever get on until the next book.  Oh, but in April, Starz will return with more episodes of the first book.  Thank goodness for that.
Not worth the wait very disappointing mostly a rehash not much new I have read the whole series and liked all the other books and looked forward to each new one that came out

I've been reading, and re-reading the Outlander series since the '90's.  Yes.  A huge fan.  With MOBY (Diana's nickname for the book)  the author seems distracted.  As well she should be...a new TV series (a delight if you have missed it), a heavy touring schedule, and all kinds of personal appearances, Gabaldon has had a wonderful few years.  Unfortunately, this book shows it.  There are something like  eight major story lines. It feels like an anthology of short stories.  Not that it isn't worth reading.  It is.  New Gabaldon fans must start with Outlander and read the series in order.  Older fans will have to read the book to keep up with the characters.  But it does feel as if we are just moving the story along a little further until the final book...rumored to be the ninth.  Diana has given me hundreds of hours of pleasure.  The story, the characters, the incredible writing will remain my favorite series for the foreseeable future.  And like the rest of her millions of fans, I will truly mourn when the series ends.  I will always remain a Gabaldon fan.  But with eight major books (by Gabaldon standards, that means 900 pages or so), and a number of smaller books not every one will be my favorite.
Outstanding! I need more!! Never have I felt characters so real. I feel I know them. And love them. I think of them often and will wait impatiently to be with them again.
Abounds  in plot holes and ends too abruptly.  Has it's lovely bits and so many sad events.  It will be a long 4 years or so until the next Big book comes out.

Like Book 7 I didn't enjoy this as much as the 1st 6.  There is too much time spent a way from from Jamie, Claire, Brianna & Roger & surrounding characters on people & events I wasn't interested in at all.  In fact it took me a long time to read this compared to the others.  I read this ended w/ a 'cliff hanger' & I was worried about what that would be.  I didn't want them all to be about to die or anything & was hoping it wouldn't be agony waiting for Book 9 to come out, which probably will be a good while yet.  The end made me smile & was comforting but, time wise, I wonder how that happened & hope it is explained in the next one, which I can patiently wait for now.  I didn't realize till I read some reviews how much repetition there is of similar violence being done, even to the same characters.  I was so caught up in what was happening at the time I didn't think "here it goes again" like others have but they are right. I hope Book 9 will focus primarily on Jamie & Claire & the immediate characters experiencing less violence & not on these others & their side stories.  I've been a big fan of this series but have been disappointed in these last 2.
It's getting redundant.
I am mildly disappointed by this long anticipated book. It took me long time to finish it while the other Outlander toms I could not put away until I finished them.
This continuation of the Outlander saga is not as sharply written as some of the preceding novels. If you have not read all of the previous novels you will be lost!

I'm a picky reader.  Love this author & this book series!  She takes her history and cultural authenticity very seriously -love that!  Too, her time travel is believable.  You get to feel like you're in Scotland or North America during those particular times.  Extremely well developed characters.  So sad when each book ends - simply to say good bye for now to the characters.  Mrs. Gabaldon's style of writing is very educated & eloquent - great vocabulary and has just sublime wording.  Unfortunately, lately it seems she has reduced the number of these rare words, now adding a parallel in simpler terms with them.  Takes some of the delight out of coming across them.  Very strong male & female leads that somehow manage to love each other over the course of their lives through hardships which we non-time-travelers can only imagine by her telling.  I highly recommend this and each of her books.  Oh, a bit more:  Mrs. Gabaldon does not fear sex scenes, so you may want to limit younger teenagers' access.  Also, she addresses homosexual relationships & adult material unapologetically - which is to say realistically.  This is not an Amish story:)
Wasn't worth the wait.
Too depressing.  They characters never get a break.  Every time they resolve one crisis, the next paragraph slams them again.  Too vicious for a comfort read
Slow at times and lengthening situations. I got bored and I've read all the books. I loved the first four books especially the Outlander which got me hooked.
Not as good as previous book . It was much easier to lay it down and not wonder what would happen next. Still I enjoyed spending time with the family again.

Gabaldon's characters are marvelously real, with smelly armpits and butt-scractching right along with the extraordinary nobility of courage, passion, loyalty and--of course!--love stories that keep you reading way beyond bedtime. Claire is wonderfully strong and independent, not some silly fluttering useless heroine--Claire is the kind of woman we'd all like to be. And Jamie, OMG Jamie! He's grown up in these books, and what a man he's turned into! Enduring much, he still retains the compassion that balances him against the mercilessness required of him at times to protect his people. One of my favorite things about Claire and Jamie is that they both continually question their personal ethics and honesty in a world that has little of either. Gabaldon's  theme of time travel is a very difficult one to carry well, but she weaves the time travel theme through her plots and subplots with skill and credibility. Gabaldon is one of the few authors of whom I always buy hardback editions--because I know I will be reading them again and again and again. One of, if not THE, favorite author of mine.
Though I call this a good read I begin to wonder if this saga has had enough. I find that it no longer holds my attention the same as the first four booke
The Outlander Saga continues with the same multiple genre writing that first attracted my attention. Can't put these novels down when I begin reading one.

The true and beautiful love story of Jamie and Claire is in the first three books in the series. Anything after that are just soap opera full of violent sex and incredible suspend-your-belief stories. In some of the books Ms. Gabaldon seems to believe that any issues between a couple can be solved by having violent sex no matter how physically wounded and bloody each of them are at the time, even for old Jamie and Claire!  As new books for the series come in more new characters are added in with their own twist and turn stories. And I believe this trend will continue with future additions. So, if you like intriguing soap operas (not unlike those lengthy Latin telenovelas, albeit of different period, of course), and rape scenes after rape scenes then you will continue to be thrilled by whatever number of books more Ms. Gabaldon is planning to write for the series. Go on, wait 5 years for each and have fun in joining Ms Gabaldon in her violent sexual fantasy. No more for me, I am tired of it, I stop here.

I've been a long time fan of Diana Gabaldon and the Outlander series.  I cried my eyes out over the first book and eagerly read each book in the series.  I'm very invested in these characters so will continue with the series.  That said, I'm struggling to get through this book.  As much as I love Jamie and Claire, their story line is boring now.  It's always the same....they travel off to war or some adventure, Claire deals with several medical emergencies,  something happens to separate them then they are reunited.  I feel like I'm stuck in a dream and reading the same story over and over.  William is the most boring character ever.  Even my favorite, Ian, is not so exciting anymore.  What I love is the story line with Brianna and Roger.  I love the mystery and all of the clues about time travel they uncover.  Rogers trip to the past and the characters we get to meet there is awesome.  Maybe it's time Jamie and Claire retire to a peaceful life and Brianna and roger take over the story.  I'm almost half way through and just praying the story picks up soon.
Another exceptional story in the Outlander series!! This is such a wonderful and historic series of books I will be saddened when I've read them all!
If you read these books for the romance, you'll love it. If, like me, you enjoy the books as historical fiction you'll be disappointed. I know I was.
Looking forward to another book?? I love the STARZ series, and the books are wonderful. Jamie is the perfect man, and Claire is so perfect as well.
Boring, long and drawn out.  Have read all the other books.  This one was the most tedious.  Could have ended the series stronger.
Diana Gabaldon does it again!  Book 8, Written in My Own Heart's Blood continues the beautiful journey of Claire & Jamie.  It does not disappoint.
Not as well developed as the previous books.Since she did not end the book now it will be another four years or so until we find out about Fergus!

this series needs to be done. there are too many random plot lines to devote decent attention to the few that are worthy. roger going back in to find Jem goes nowhere and drags on forever and ever. i have never liked bree and she does nothing in this book to make me change my mind, she is still a dithering idiot. Ian and rachel and marsali and Fergus are good, though Marsali and Fergus are treated as after-thoughts for the most part. I like the bit about lord john, his adventrue is interesting, and his brother is a feisty component too. William, on the other hand, is a whiny petulant child, not a grown man. it feels like this entire book was devised around the idea of him, and he is not up to the challenge. even jamie and claire seem tired of the whole shebang. I  am a huge fan of this series, I have handed out "outlander" to 20 or so people, creating new addicts =) but it needs to end. the last 3 books have been less than good, and this one is fairly yucky.

As a devoted fan, I enjoyed it, but I felt the book might have benefitted from some very judicious editing. There were tangential story lines I thought were unnecessary and stalled the true narrative.  For the first ever in the series, I found myself flat out bored. Ms. Gabaldon's soaring imagination is remarkable, but there was just far too much going on, and involving people or events I simply didn't care about. The cast of characters is already enormous. A whirlwind pace is all well and good, but the events in this book more closely resembled a whirling dervish; flying madly through space to land briefly here, then there, and what? what just happened?  And to whom?  I love these books, but this one took work, a lot of it.  It's an uphill read and I can't honestly say that's an enjoyable experience. I would never say Ms. Gabaldon has lost her way, but I do believe she should wander less frequently from the path that make this one of the best book series ever.

I've stayed current with this series because I've enjoyed the concept, the writing style, etc. And of course, I can't help but wonder what the next one will be.  But to be truthful, I struggled to finish this book.  It was just ok.  And that's how I felt about the last book in the series, maybe the one before that, too.  To be truthful, the best book in the series, in my opinion, was Dragonfly In Amber, the second in series, which I absolutely loved.  Budget was also a good one too.  Those were 5+ stars for me.  One must read the first book for characters and context and series story beginning,but it was pretty much a thinly veiled bodice ripper with a sci fi, historical fiction trying to cover that up.  However by the end of the first book, I did want to know what happened next, ergo the fact that I have bought and read every book in the series.  I would be fine, in fact happy, if this were the book that wraps up the series.  I felt like it jumped the shark last book or so but this is a respectable completion.

Just in time! I was getting close to forgetting what was happening and to whom in this continuing series. If your like me, you will have to refer back to the previous book to find your bearings. But it will be worth it! It's clear that the author is capable of aging the story and it's characters in a believable fashion. Interestingly, the humor in Ms. Gabaldon's writing seems to have waned in this book, especially if you compare it to her first book. This story also has less in it about Jamie than I would like to have. The addition of a Quaker wife in the story is interesting and makes Ian's character relevant again. The story sets up the next book to move the story back to Frasier's Ridge and the Revolutionary War and its effect on the family. Also, the time travel aspect is explored a little in interesting ways. Roger actually meets his long lost father who accidentally became a time traveler! I liked this installment to the Outlander series, Hope it won't be 4 years before the next book!
Too much shifting places and rvents around and characters not staying true to their values. I wonder if someone else but Gabledon wrote it.
I love this series.  As many others do, I wait as patiently as possible for the next book to be written.  Ms Gabaldon is an amazing author.

Like many fans, I waited years for this book to come out. And, now that I've read it, well, it seems I'll be waiting years for the next one too. Because as much as I LOVED this book, and I really did love it, it doesn't have a very satisfying ending. I've kept up with all the Lord John novels and the in-between novellas - so I thought I had a pretty firm grasp of what was going on -- so while a few loose ends where tied up in this book (rather nicely) so many, MANY, more threads were just left dangling at the end of MOBY. As much as I love the characters in this series, I don't really want to read about them getting busy with each other in their 80's. I want a happy, just, satisfying ending before I have to start picturing Jamie and Claire as geriatrics.
Does not compare with the other books in the series.  Maybe Gabaldon was concentrating too much on getting the television series launched.
I was disappointed.

As usual, Diana Gabaldon had produced a fascinating, gripping, interesting, emotion-grabbing, historically accurate, story. Another huge book that is hard to put down. Our familiar characters from the Outlander series have become very real to those of us who have followed their lives from their youth in Scotland to the Revolutionary war times. The author has a great knack for developing her characters as they move through life, aging them appropriately, and never losing their "flavor"--their characters just grow richer. This book picks up the story from the many cliff hangers of the previous book ( which left readers screaming in frustration). This book has many threads to be followed in book nine, but nevertheless has a very satisfying ending. Highly recommended (but if you have not read the prior books in this series, please start with book one, Outlander, and it will all mean so much more to you).
Disappointed after a long wait.  Unsatisfying resolution to the situation for the younger generations.  Gratuitous murder at the end.
A joy as always :) gripping. Moving. Inspiring. I didn't want it to end!!! Anxiously awaiting the continuation. I love this author!!
I was very disappointed in this book. It was nothing like I expected.  Did not care for it at all.
I have loved all the other "Outlander" books but I found this one disappointing.  It did not hold my interest like the others did.
Not as good as the early books in the series. Following the additional threads with new characters is a little confusing at times
Not as believable as her other books.  Too much time spent  on  the sex scenes and jumping around with the characters and time.
I love this series. Unfortunately, I felt that this book was nothing more than a filler. It was good, but definitely not great.
A great ending book!  Got a little bogged down at times, but good to get back into reading the series.  It's been a long time!
Continues the wonderful story and characters that I have grown to know and love...will be difficult to wait for the next book!

I loved the first seven books in the Outlander series. I have even begun to reread them since finishing Book 8. However, I have to admit to being disappointed by the rushed conclusion that Book 8 provided. I felt that some scenes were drawn out until they almost became boring. Then, as the book neared the end, I felt it was rushed to a final conclusion that left out details of how the events came to occur. I'm not disappointed by the final conclusions, just the rush and leap the author took to get there. I didn't feel that all of the plot lines were wrapped up in the end. I was afraid that that's what would happen when I found out the original publication date had been pushed back because of the author's involvement in the casting and filming of the new Outlander series on Starz. Since I have gone back and started Book 1 again, I will probably read this one again too. Just to complete my reread.
It's time to wrap it up, Diana. We have loved the saga tremendously, but sadly it has become old and tired in this last book.
Not the best book in the series, usually I love the story line of Jamie and Claire, but this book seemed abit same old thing.

I absolutely LOVE this whole series and it is consistently good from beginning to this 8th book.  Gabaldon is an excellent, excellent writer and has awesome editors.  I am anal about editing and I may have found one error in all 8 books put together.  But that is not the main reason I love these books.  Gabaldon's characters are REAL and I became invested in them.  This is one of those books that you can't wait to get back to.  Sometimes I would think, hmmm...can't wait to see what Jamie and Claire are up to.  While I wait, hopefully, for the 9th book in this series, I am going to read the Lord John Grey books by Gabaldon.  John Grey is a supporting character in the Outlander series, but Gabaldon has done such a great job with the character portrait that I can't wait to see what he is up to also.  I read A LOT and I believe this is the best crafted, best storyline I have ever read!!

I loved the last book in the series as much as the first! Jamie and Claire and the extended family and friends continue to experience a wild and crazy ride and though mature now, their love story is just as beautiful as ever. This book takes place in large part during the Revolutionary War, but there is an interesting story line with Roger, Bree and their children that takes them back to the 1980s and has them living at Lallybroch (Jamie Fraser's birth home). Since I just read all 8 books in a row, I am going to feel a little lost without them in my life now and absolutely can't wait until the next book arrives...although I think I have a while to wait!  I am just going to have to hope the TV series on Starz keeps going so I can relive the books.  I think DG is an amazing and intelligent writer and she definitely challenges me to the max with words I have to look up to understand.

The problem with sequels is trying to tell an interesting continued story for those who have read the prequel yet explaining past events for new readers.  The explanations bog down the story line and distract.  This book had too many lines and too much thrown in.  In the end it was all wrapped up but you had to be patient to get there.  Garbaldon strength is in throwing in interesting antecedent information such as how to make penicillin and also the ordinary stuff like using the privy.  All the time traveling is getting unbelievable.  She did throw in a missed time mistake with Roger to make it more believable then throws in more and super po wers.  Really.  I also agree the frequent rape stuff as well as all the detailed Jaime/Claire sex is getting old.  But still a good read.  My primary genre is mystery and suspense but thus series keeps my attention and gives me a gore break.
This book was OK but not one of the best in the series. Too much about Lord John and family and not enough Jamie and Clair.

As usual, Diana writes in great detail.  You can picture in your mind what is happening.  I can't put my finger on why, but this book seemed a bit "dis-joined" and slow.  Several times I felt like saying, "let's get on with it, already".  I've had a hard time putting all the other Outlander books down.  I had difficulty picking this one up because I was bored through a lot of the book.  I just wanted to get it over with so I could start a new book.  My husband was reading it at the same time I was.  I waited until the end of the book to discuss my feelings about the book because I didn't want to influence his feelings about it.  When we started discussing it, he began bringing up the same things I felt about it.  After waiting four years, it was disappointing.  I hope Diana,s creativity has not run dry, because nobody paints a picture with words like she does.

I was really looking forward to this book and the first two sections were great (one on Jamie and Claire, one on Brianna and Roger).  I had missed all the characters and it was great to catch up with them. However, after those sections, I felt the book got bogged down in the Revolutionary War.  The author must be quite a history buff.  The book became a pleasant read for 1/2 an hour before bedtime, but was certainly not a page turner that I couldn't bear to put down!  It was difficult at times to remember events that occurred several books ago that were relevant to the story.  The author does provide some explanations and reminders which were helpful.  After reading the ending of the book, I did not get the impression that there will be any more sequels.  That's sad but the author seems to have run out of enthusiasm for the story and it is no longer exciting.
Absolutely fabulous series!!  Once you start, you can't stop reading!!  The start line and characters fully draw you in!
Although I have loved all her previous books, this one was a disappointment. Not as well written, and somewhat preachy.

It was SO great to finally read more about the lives of Jamie and Claire as well as all of the other characters. After all these books and all these years they are like old friends that were missed. So much happened in this book as is true of all of Diana's other books. There is never a dull moment. There is everything in this book, love, hate, war, romance, sex, tragedy and triumph. Some of the events were surprising and shocking but all were amazing. I waited years to read this book and it was well worth he wait. I like the fact that Diana talked in this book about things that happened in previous books. When I got to the last page, I actually said out loud, "NO IT CAN'T END THERE!", but it did. I really hope Diana writes another book to continue with this story. Even if I have to wait a few years to read it. Amazing work Diana!! Keep it up!!!
Excellent!! Ranks right there with all the rest of the series! One of those books you think about through out the day.

I have read the whole Outlander series and it is great. Even if you haven't read the whole series, WRITTEN IN MY OWN HEART'S BLOOD can be read by someone who hasn't, but don't do that - read all of them. Diana Gabaldon will suck you in with her historical - time travel books. They are full of twists and turns and jam packed with adventure and romance. The only problem is I already miss them. I have to wait and hope there is a book nine, so I can spend more time with Jamie and Claire Frazer. If you are watching Outlander on Starz TV and enjoy the story, do yourself a favor and read the books - there is so much more to enjoy within the books.
