Also, I started to purchase the audio when I purchased the books. For a few dollars more you can listen and read. The person who narrated the books did a great job with the accents and was fun to hear.

*SPOILER ALERT*  I enjoyed this installment in the series almost as much as the first book (which is still my favorite of all of them).  The end did have strange twist with a presumed dead character returning - I can only imagine that little bit will continue into the next book.  You will also find out the fate of some of the other main characters and time travelers, but there is still a lot to uncover about them.  There is a lot of long drawn out scenes with the war.  While it helped to refresh my memory of the American Revolution, some of it was a bit out there (really, just happening upon George Washington?).  I enjoyed more story about John Grey and Willie and the relationship between John and Willie and Jamie and Claire is tested and I'm sure will be developed more in future book(s).  Looking forward to the next book already.
Well worth the wait!  I simply loves these characters and will reread as I have done all the others.  Thanks Diana.
Not as good as expected.  More time was spent " wrapping up" rather than the traditional awesome storyline.

This book is not as good as some in the series.  Although I was on the edge of my seat for most of the book, at the end I was a bit let down.  True, she has to have room for another volume and perhaps what will take place in the next one is a bit too obvious in this book, but I spent almost all the time it took to read it wondering "what about Brianna and Rodger?".  I have loved almost all of the books in this series and have even spoken to numerous strangers who I've seen reading one of Gabaldon's books.  We all agree that this series rocks!  I'm giving it four stars because, although the story is not predictable, it wasn't as exciting and nailbiting as some of the others.  In essence, it was a good read, but she's done better.  This book gets four stars from me, whereas others (many) have gotten the full five.

After waiting so long after the last book, I wanted to fall in love with this one. I like the author's writing style, the Jamie / Claire storyline is compelling, and the combination of time travel and historical novel works well for me. The plot lines jumped around a lot, but reading the ASOIAF books trained me to follow along. In general, I was happy with this book, and it ended in a way that makes me want to read the next one. What didn't work for me was this: On one hand, there was endless detail about war strategy and the movement of soldiers, and on the other hand, this book reads more like a romance novel than its predecessors. The combination of love and war can make a wonderful story, but in this case it didn't flow well. Going little lighter on both military and mushiness would have balanced it out a bit.

When someone first suggested I read that Outlander series, they described it to me as a romance novel. I had no interest and she insisted I give it a try and I've been hooked ever since. While there is romance, it's so much more on so many levels. This latest installation was truly excellent! I was excited to reunite with all of the characters. It was fun and interesting to run into some old favorites in a different time. I laughed, cried and was caught by surprise in this book - as I have all of them. I always hate to give spoilers, so I'll just say, if you've enjoyed the previous novels, you must read this. I can't recommend this series enough. Anytime anyone asks for recommendations, I always tell them to read Outlander. I will follow the Fraser clan for as long as Diana Gabaldon decides to write about them.
I love Diana's Outlander series and looked forward to MOBY.  However,  this book is so boring I finally gave up.

I LOVED this book!  Even if you have not read the other books in the series, you will still be able to follow the story lines as Diana does a great job of making the book interesting and relevant to newbies as well as loyal fans.  However, I strongly encourage you to read the other books in order before reading this one because they are FABULOUS and make this book so much more meaningful.  This book resolves the agonizing cliff hanger she left us with at the end of An Echo in the Bone.  But just when you think things are calming down in the story, Diana throws in twists and turns that make this a book you just cant put down.  (Just like the other books in the series!)  Needless to say, I'm a huge fan of this series and this book didn't disappoint.  Highly recommended! (BUT READ THE OTHER BOOKS FIRST :))

Finally!!! The next book in Diana's monumental OUTLANDER series that all of us have been waiting for. As always, it is written in her own unique and fascinating style, with so much detail that you believe you are there with the characters instead of just reading along. If you have never read a Diana Gabaldon Jamie and Claire book you might be a bit lost to come in at this juncture, but it certainly takes up where the last book left us (and then left us in a cliffhanger!), and then moves on from there. All the characters, present time and past time, are imaculately drawn, and the switching from the story in the present to the story in the past moves smoothly and easely. The only challenge I had was keeping the minor characters straight! Perhaps an updated "Outlandish Companion" is in order!

You shouldn't ask me - I am a NUMBER ONE Gabaldon fan.  I feel Claire and Jamie et al are so well written and understandable that I know them personally.  I have been waiting four years for this one to come out. I think she's one of the very best authors of our time.  When her history isn't spot on, she tells you why it isn't - the dialogue is so rich and real - I just wish I could read Gaelic (Scots and Irish). When Claire applies her 20th century medical abilities to the restrictions of 18th century reality, she does it right - however improbably it might seem. Before The Outlander came out, my favorite single book was Gone With the Wind, whch I have read seven times.  I am now preparing to begin at the beginning, and re-discover all of the Outlander books again.  Obviously, I LOVE IT!
A little disjointed.  Seemed like someone else wrote some chapters.  Not near as good as all the other books.

From one who has read the whole Outlander series, devouring each page as I went, I found this follow up to be a little flat. Usually I find I'm swept up in a world I refuse to put down from start to finish, coming up for air only long enough to put leftovers on the table again for the family. This time I felt the storyline was a bit disjointed, it lacked the flow and suspense the previous books had. Not to say I didn't read it in a timely matter, I certainly did. It just didn't rank a 5 star like previous books would have. Maybe Diana was finding herself spread too thin with all the publicity of the new miniseries. The ending although there are still many loose ends did have a ring of finality, which was sad. I certainly hope not, but all good things must come to an end sometime.

There are too many characters in this book and they do too many things. I think William was dealt poorly with. His ending seems left hanging and since I imagine this is the last of the outlander series I wish she'd left the completely boring battles out of this last book and dealt more fairly and less choppily with the Grey's and Fraser's and their families. The deaths don't bother me. Death is a part of life. The anger and indecision and so on with William and Jamie and Lord John seems to have been handled in such an offhand way and very little seemed finished. Fergus and Percy for instance. Also, Captain Richardson. So, will there be other books or are we left hanging once again? Thus the the 3 stars.

Well written, as usual, but story theme is weakening more with each subsequent novel. Covers family activities during the American Revolution but the family has increased so much to additional characters that it's slowly become a study in character as opposed to a tale covering time. It's a family history continued if that is what the reader wants to follow. I normally read continuously when I get and Outlander Series book but found myself having to remind myself to pick this one up to read and complete. Like I said, well written but the overall genre has begun to weaken a bit. I will pick up my original Outlander and re-read it once more before buying any further versions. The end obviously is set to lead up to the next volume so be prepared for that soon. Happy reading.
I love love love this series but this book seemed to drag on and the story just never really came together.

As always excellent writing. I am very happy with the ending as it is not a cliffhanger like Echo in the Bone. As much as I love this series and characters, I am ready for the story to end. In fact not sure I will even read another book unless it is the final book. Enough already, how many more times can someone be kidnapped? How many more hideous injuries and near death illnesses can be suffered by the main characters? Too many main characters now as well. It is hard to be enthused about Hal, Ben, Denzel Hunter, Hal's children and all. Breath of Snow and Ashes is the best written of the series and these last two books while still good, feel forced and have too many people to keep track of.

I loved the earlier Outlander Series books so I was excited to read this one. Unfortunately, it didn't hold my interest as well as the others. IMHO the book is far too long. Historical characters are introduced and a tidbit or two about each of them are included, but in the end, their presence does little to advance the story which drags on and on. Towards the end of the book I wondered if the author felt "Oh, let's get this over with already." It takes far too long for the two major threads of the plot to come together and when they do, it's abruptly, incompletely and without enough description. Something is left dangling so I assume there'll be book 9. Don't think I'll buy it.

This is the on going story of Jamie and Clair as they make their way through the twists and turns of surviving times of war.  One might think with such a long lasting series that it would grow a bit dull or repetitive, not so!  As the story progresses you watch the families and friends of the Frasers grow up and have their own adventures and challenges from various perspectives.  One of my very favorite features of this series is that each book ends in such a way as to leave the reader both thrilled and yet satisfied.  As when having just enjoyed a truly fantastic meal with the ideal wine and exactly the right dessert, it leaves you warm and very pleased with the entire experience. I eagerly look forward to your next installment! Well done Gabaldon!

I love this series but often lose my momentum as I wait 4 or so years between books. During this time I forget plot elements and multiple side characters so that several times in the book I'm like "who?".  Having said that, many of the 8 books are really 4 out of 5 "filler" books without a huge amount of useful content that moves the plot along.  This book does NOT disappoint!  Adds a couple of interesting characters.  Further fills out other more interesting characters. Altogether extremely enjoyable. I do wish the author would just focus on this series and put out the books more often though.  Waiting almost half a decade for a new book in a series is a bit much and I've not found the side "Lord John" series very enjoyable

This was one of the best in series! The Americsn Revolution was so well written that it transported me right into the past and INTO THE ACTION. I felt as though I was actually there! The scenes were so vivid and real in sequences. Licences were drawn where they could have actually been accurate...using real last names and places into the fictional characters/places, i.e. Gen. Fraser in Battle of Saratoga, his death, burial and subsequent transfer to Scotland for burial at home. Loved the wedding scene! Tears, laughter and a joyful ending! There's still room for another book to tie-up loose ends with other supporting characters and go deeper into relationships through their courage and faith. Thus, making me ask "when" the next book is due?

If this were the last one in the series I could live with it, it's that good. Don't want it to be the last one, though! A Must Read. Keep a hanky close by and be prepared for some shocking, tragic and also poignant moments.  Life really does move on. Its been 20 years since I've started this series and it's just as fresh and wonderful today as it was then. I finished reading this then watched the Stars production. (Which is OMG wonderful!) And it was a little surreal "seeing" Claire and Jamie young again after reading this last book.  If you have never read an Outlander novel you have a great journey ahead of you. If, like me,  you have been reading the series for a while...savor it. I've already read it twice and I want to read it again!

I have waited so long for another Outlander book, having enjoyed the series immensely.  Reading this felt like a return to old friends but the story itself seemed a bit disjointed and not as meaty as previous books. As a stand alone, it would not work very well at all but I take it as a long awaited re-introduction to the family of Claire and Jamie Fraser. Now don't get me wrong, I thoroughly enjoyed reading the book and with the way this one ends I know there will be another on the way (soon, I hope!). Rather than a complete story, this one has the feel of several chapters that have not yet come to any purpose or resolution. Those of us who are rabid Outlander fans won't care, though, and will eat it up, hungry and waiting anxiously for more.
Becoming mindless drivel.  Time to end this series.  Used to love them but they are now a tedious read.
A little slow.
Just amazing that I don't tire of this group of characters. Will miss them until the next book is out!
Much too much coverage of the Revolutionary War battles.  I was more interested in the time travelers.

I love the way Ms. Gabaldon writes.  So engaging.  This, the 8th in the series, was as wonderful as the previous ones.  I love how she educates us on historical events (I've learned a lot about Scottish and US Revolutionary history I did not know), and on issues we encounter in life, dealing with spouses, medical issues, botany things, wedding night sex, all very entertaining AND informative.  Good on you, Ms. Gabaldon.  this one leaves an opening for a 9th (surprise)... but she says it takes her four years to write one of the "big" books... so we'll see how much stamina she has.  AND I'm eager to see how the big reunion goes.  I don't know how Jamie and Claire live through all of their tribulations... but they have so far!

I feel very fortunate to have discovered these books as this 8th one was released.  I was able to read all 8 back-to-back in about 2.5 months.  I feel for those that had to wait 4 years between books, spanning 20+ years.  However, I realize I am now in that boat; it will be 4 years until the 9th and final (?) book is released.  I agree with others that there is significant detail on herbs, historical figures, and whatnot that I may skim over in later books, but, if this is what it takes to satisfy the author to tell a complete story, I will not complain too much.  No one compares to her storytelling skills that I have found.  It will be a long 4 years...

This is Gabaldon's eighth book in the Outlander series. Outlander fans adore the Jamie/Claire story but it's seriously time for Gabaldon to wind down this series. With the massive infusion of cash into her bank account that the Starz series has brought let's hope Gabaldon will finally conclude the tale. Her writing has become predictable and sloppy. The stories are rambling and disjointed as she works feverishly to develop her secondary characters. This forces readers to lurch from character to character. While MOBY is a marked improvement over Echo the later books pale in comparison to her first works. These beloved characters need an end and so do we.

I am a fan of her series but found the last novel droned on and on about the Revolutionary war and I had high hopes that her most recent release, My Own Heart's Blood, would make some improvements on that.  But it didn't, this book was a huge disappointment, excruciating to get through and in the end felt like a waste of my time.  I'm not so sure I'd be willing to read another either.  This novel doesn't compare to her earlier work....the story line is all over the place, way too much war filler....I feel like the author lost focus and the original feel and richness of her storytelling.  I wouldn't recommend this book....and it makes me sad to say that.

Fantastic, brilliant, amazing! Another wonderful installment in the lives of Claire and Jamie Fraser. I loved the ending, how it wasn't a cliffhanger but still left some unanswered questions which will be answered in the next book. What I loved most about the book, was what makes all the books so wonderful - and that's the deep abiding love that Jamie and Claire have for each other. You just know, from the straight out declarations to the subtle glances and touches, that these two were truly meant to be! Lots of historical figures come to play and there are a couple of sad losses, but a superb continuation to what is possibly my favourite book series.

New Diana Gabaldon Outlander novel is okay. I was expecting more on the story of Roger & Bree but seems most of the novel was a repeat of how Jamie Fraser & Clare were doing & not much on the whole story line about the kidnapping & Roger in time travel except that he meet his father. I was kind of bored with this one but it did have some good moments. I hope the next one will focus more on Roger & Bree now that they have made it back in time to Fraser's Ridge. I also kind of predicted that as I was reading the book so that was too obvious. It is an okay read but I wasn't that excited about it & now hope the next one will be a little more lively.

I have read every "Outlander" book and Jamie and Claire have become part of my family. I have looked forward to every new book and have treated it as a giant piece of candy. Anxious to consume it but dragging it out to the end to last longer. I know a movie is coming out but I have "cast" my characters just the way I see them and can't imagine spoiling that with how "Hollywood" sees them. Besides, no person exists today with the beauty and elegance described by Diana Gabaldon. Many thanks to the author for giving me hours of enjoyment. I have preached to my grand babies that "reading" is better than any TV show because it is the magic of your imagination and will belong to you forever.

As much as I loved this series, I am ready for it to end.  I am much older now then when the first book was published and I had to go back and re-read some parts of her earlier books so that I could remember what happened.  Now I will have to wait for another book to be published.  In the beginning with books 1-5 I couldn't wait to devour the next book.  I bought this book months ago and I just now finished it.  It took me a few months to even start it.  I think part of the reason I rated this book a 3 was it didn't hold my attention as much as the first ones.  Don't get me wrong I love Jamie and Clare.  I just want them to finally get to relax and enjoy their life together. So please let the next book be the last.

I'm disappointed in this most recent Outlander book. Far too many people to keep track of. Far too many places, times, plots and details to keep them all straight. I found myself slogging through this book. I had to force myself to finish it and it felt like work. Between reading her last book and finally getting my hands on this one, I read and THOROUGHLY enjoyed Sara Donati's Wilderness Series. Donati wrote a six book series that is essentially the same as the Outlander set, but well told and without the endless science fiction stones absurdity. I strongly recommend Sara Donati's books. Skip this and any subsequent Outlander books.

Written in My Own Heart's Blood brings together all of the side stories of the Fraser and Grey families.  Because their were so many side stories, I had to go back and re-read the novels in order from Drums in Autumn forward. It helped me organize the story lines so I didn't lose track of who was where in this book. Written in My Own Heart's Blood is very well written, and makes you realize just why you got wrapped up in the series. There was so many side stories in the prior two novels that I was worried I wouldn't enjoy this book. No so.  Readers of the Outlander books will be very happy with this latest novel.  I am hoping there will be at least one more, bringing the rest of the Fraser clan together again.

I started to read the Outlander books when I was involved in study abroad and spent a good deal of time in Scotland.  This new, long time coming, continuation of the series is full of time travel, bold Scots, and a heady mixture of adventure and romance.  If you are new to the series, I suspect you will find it hopelessly confusing.  You would be better served by going back to The Outlander and reading the series in order.  The series is, I have heard, being made into a TV series of some sort, so fans will enjoy that as well.  I will add that the history in the books is quite accurate, including a lot of detail about how people lived in Scotland and the U.S. during the time period.  A fine, swashbuckling read.
So very disappointed after enjoying the other books in the series.Not worth the time or the money.
Tied things up nicely, although it felt a little rushed at times, like "checking the box."

I LOVE THIS ENTIRE SERIES. This book is one in the OUTLANDER series by Diana Gabaldon. While it is possible to read and enjoy it on its own, the series is so spectacular, you'd be cheating yourself by not starting at the beginning with book #1, OUTLANDER. The story is riveting, full of twists and turns, Machiavellian plots & intrigues, romance (of course), as well as 18th century history and life. And you will love the central characters. While romance is a definite part of the series, this is not a cheesy romance novel The author's attention to period detail and history is exceptional. The series begins in Scotland, but that is only the beginning! Gabaldon is a talented and prolific writer. Anyone who enjoys historical novels will love this series.

Not her best but an entertaining summer read.  The details, Gabaldon's hallmark of historical fiction, are superb yet border on the tedious in the revolution sections.  I kept waiting for something to happen but plodded on.  It just isn't up to her usual standard of excitement and adventure.  There is so much emphasis on the Grey's and little of Brianna and her family.  Still, the characters are true to their original depictions and are as well developed as ever, and of course the door is open to another sequel.  I recommend it to her fans, but don't attempt this book without a thorough background of the Outlander series.

I just finished it the night before last, and my only regret is that it's over. It's the last of 8 books in the "Outlander" series, and I hope Diana Gabaldon writes a ninth. The characters have become a part of my life, and I will miss them. This expansive series of books has everything! Time travel, adventure, romance, history, sex, and rich portrayals of characters! Gabaldon is an amazing author who has written a timeless and amazing series of books! I've never been much for studying history, but the "Outlander" series gives an up close, personal view of history, experienced through the eyes of a modern person. It's rich and engaging, and I can't recommend it strongly enough!

Diana Gabaldon is a very satisfying historical/romance writer.  Her genre is well researched and she combines many facets of scientific facts for the time period in history her books are set in. I have read all of the Outlander Series books several times and enjoy them each and every time.  Written in My Own Heart's Blood is a well written addition to the series. Bridging between colonial America and 1980's Scotland makes this particular book a joy to read.  I learn new words and old words used during the time period with every book Gabaldon writes.  This next installment in the series is written at the same level as the other books. Love the series and just ask Gabaldon to keep 'em commin'.

Although I enjoyed the book, it wasn't my favorite of the series.  The narrative seemed a little chopped up this time and transitions between the two time periods didn't seem as smooth.  I felt that there were too many references to events from previous novels .  I guess it was done perhaps to satisfy new readers who hadn't read the previous books.  I got a little bored with Claire and Jamie's involvement with the Revolution.  I felt like it was just a vehicle to throw in some famous names and too many pages were spent on those  encounters in my opinion.  Claire's evolving expertise from nurse to surgeon does require a bit of a suspension of disbelief but all in all a pretty good read.

I think this marvelous author kinda lost her way with this bk....drifted into such long, over done descriptions of medical instruments and procedures, people just getting frm one area to another/journeys that went for pages on end.....I think her outlander series should be drawn to a conclusion....I could not believe how bored I was getting with this..unlike I did with her past OUTLANDER books....this one just did not not "hit the mark" almost didn't complete it and did a lot of speed reading. I can't. believe I'm saying this but I will not be reading any further books in this series......Ms. Garbaldon should leave them all on the Ridge, to live "happily ever after"

This is Gabaldon's best work since the original Outlander. Some of the books in between lost me  in an overload of detail and not much excitement. However, this book did not disappoint. I really enjoyed hearing from several different characters throughout the novel instead of relying solely on Claire's point of view. What this book had that previous others did not was suspense. There were times I felt like I could not put the book down. I thoroughly enjoyed that we visit several time periods in this book and met characters we never thought we would meet. The ending is a bit of a cliff hanger, as usual, and makes me hope we will see another Outlander book sooner rather than later!

I worried that I had forgotten many of the miscellaneous characters from the earlier books.  I needn't have worried.  Diana Gabaldon is a wonderful writer!  I was able to pick the threads back up easily with her subtle reminders of the previous situations and people.  It just flowed.  This time I bought the kindle version to enjoy on my iPad. Maybe a mistake as my iPad glowed late into the nights and again in the wee hours of the mornings.  When she writes, the characters seem so real.  How will I be able to wait four more years for another sequel?  I feel I'm aging right along with Claire.  The historical research is amazing and every detail makes you feel you are right there.

I have read every page of this Outlander series and love the characters Diana has created to tell her story. However, this latest book "Written in My Own Heart's Blood" was a tougher read. Too much time spent on details of the war and not enough time spent on the complicated relationships between Jamie, Lord John and William. I'm proud to say I struggled thru this book and loved the ending. The story of Brianna and her family kept me interested in the middle. I'd say it was worth the read but hope the next book in this series is more about the characters and less about war and government.

I like this one and appreciated that the end of the book ended on a surprising happy note.  This was particularly nice given the serious situation Bree and family were in near the beginning and that there were deaths to several secondary characters. I think we all keep reading these because we want to know how things end for Jamie and Claire. But, I have to say that I didn't mind some of the secondary stories as much as I did in the previous books. I feel invested in the lives of Bree/Roger, Ian/Roger, John Grey, and William (and more).  I really can't wait for book 9.  In the mean time, I've started reading all the side books to fill in some of the character back stories.

Ms Gabaldon is a true wordsmith with a refreshing vocabulary, romantic turn of a phrase, and an ability to make history vividly personal. I enjoyed the growth of each character, and being on the edge hoping that those I grew to love didn't perish.  Characters are passionate, colorful, humanly faulted, and we'll fleshed out. I enjoyed the intertwinement of lives and layers of plot. There were moments where I paused to contemplate; my own life, the course of action I would've taken, to savor a strong emotion, to be angry with a character, or to look up a word. This has been an engrossing adventure, which is now gratefully become part of my own experience.  Thank you Diana.

I know what the other reviewers are saying, and they have a right to their view. That being said, I cannot say anything I disliked about the book. Mrs. G. entertained me, enthralled me, and yes I sniffed and cried at times. I finished the whole caboodle feeling heart warmed and happy. But I shamelessly love and am in love with the Frasier Clan. What more can you ask of a good book? I say if your into the saga this far then take this book for what it is (and it's great :) Don't compare it to her earlier works. Just enjoy her story. Jaime and Claire are growing older and so is their story. It maybe can't be as fresh as the start for some, but for me it's amazing! Ya ken?
Seems to have lost the balance between war, and activity between the ages - way to much war.
Not as spell binding as her original Highlander Series at all... I haven't even finished it.

Book of COURSE was excellent.  There didn't seem to be as much Jamie and Clair togetherness adventures however, it carries the story forward and it was great to see the younger generation moving forward as well.  I cannot wait until the next one.  The problem with these books is that they are sooooo good and once you read the latest one, you hate to wait for the next, knowing it will be a year or more.  However, I just keep listening or reading to them over and over and never get tired of them;it only heightens the excitement of waiting on the next.  I suppose it may have to end but I think the Jamie and Clair story has another few books. (I hope)!  Fantastic writer.

I have been reading this series from the beginning and absolutely love it.  I keep checking for the next book to come out.  This one seemed a long time in coming, and I ordered it as soon as it was out.  Diana has a way of making these characters very real, I love the way they all match and seem so real for the timeline.  Jamie and Claire are my favorites, and this book revisited many of the past characters and just brought them all together in the story line.  I do hope that there will be several more to the series, don't want to leave them all homeless on Fraser's Ridge, especially now that the family is all together.  Very good series and I recommend it to many.

I am a huge Diana Gabaldon fan, and I loved this book just like I loved all of her other "big" books.  I have her 5 stars because she is committed to excellent research and she always delivers something new and interesting that I didn't know before.  In this book, she focuses on the customs of Quakers because of the relationship between young Ian and Rachel.  Her characters are all well developed and real.  Her characters are unforgettable!  The only thing about this book that I was not in favor of was the supernatural element that allowed Bree to find Roger- It was the only time in the entire series that I felt let down because it was just not believable.

You could have taken away 300 pages, and still told the same thing! Seemed to be a lot of detailed war and battle stuff (filler) that was unnecessary. In my opinion the series is supposed to be about Claire and Jamie. They were lost amounts the  (stuff)!  There was no sense to the kiddnapping of Jem which I don't believed was told enough to resolve anything and how at the end did Bree Dog and kids make it to the Ridge from the time zone in the past (40) yes or so and also how is a late 60+ woman able to have so much sex without hormones and run down the mountain with Jamie to see the kids at the end?? Please let ME write the LAST book in this series PLEASE!!!!!
Good, but a bit repetitive, too much of a rehash, IMO. Perhaps a "fan's only" book.

Diana Gabaldon is a fantastic writer and does her research extremely well.  When I read the first book in the Outlander series, I thought I would never grow tired of any of the characters.  Alas, I was wrong.  I love Jamie and Claire, thier love story....but I am afraid I have just grown weary of the story.  I'm afraid I couldn't even finish this book.  The television series has no pull on me.  Ms Gabaldon, I hope that you will write another series with different characters to love who have no knowledge of the characters in Outlander, and one that doesn't extend 10 plus years.

What can I say?  You find an author that can write like this once in a lifetime!  I'm not really a fan of romance novels, but this woman doesn't just write about romance, she has fully captured unconditional love and a soul- wrenching telling of the American Revolution from both perspectives.  A masterpiece of historical writing revolving around characters that the reader has fallen in love with all of hiis/her heart.  This author held my own heart in her hand the entire time I was reading the Outlander series and I lamented that this was her last book.  Each book stands on its own, but it's so much better if you read them all.  It is a MUST READ!!!

I'm a fan and have been looking forward to the latest installment. I avoided looking at reviews until I finished it. I find I agree with many who say it's not Gabaldon at her best, however I can't bring myself to give such a terrific writer who I've enjoyed so much over the years less then a star rating of "I like it." I was an American History major with a concentration in Early American Studies, but I admit to glazing over with the military detail. I yearned for the primary characters' stories to move along further in this installment. I felt put off, but with all honesty, I'll be signing up for the next book like a good Outlander devotee.

We started the series by listening to the audio versions of The first three books in the Outlander series several years ago (on cassettes).  I started catching up by reading the following novels in quick succession on my e-reader.  I have followed Diana Gabaldon on social media as she was finishing this latest book in the series.  Once again, the story combines a healthy dose of believable magic with practical 20th century science, contemporary knowledge and Revolutionary War history.  The reader learns to love, hate (and both) and know each character.  I always hate when one of Ms. Gabaldon's books end but I can't put them down until they do!

I began reading the Outlander Series approximately 16 years ago and have been hooked ever since.  I have read each and every one of Diana Gabaldon's (hope I spelled that correctly) I am on the last one right now.  There are so many unpredictable twists and turns which kept me on the edge of my seat.  I enjoy the history which I feel Diana has explored and covered so well and the family dynamics.  I am thrilled that STARZ has made a series from her books.  Season one barely covers book one.  I am anxiously awaiting Season 2 so I can put faces to the characters I have only imagined as I read the books.  Would definitely recommend these books.
Excellent but it's getting kind of redundant.  I don't think she can pass it to Brianna?
Too much rambling about inconsequential events.  The whole book seemed "forced".

It's not my favorite by far of all the books.  The first three books still remain in that spot.  However, I loved how Diana interwove the multiple story lines, having the most of the characters interact with each other at certain intersections like a tapestry.  I thought "Tapestry" would have been a more appropriate title. I am not sure how the title fitted into the story. Obviously, I must have missed a crucial piece of the tapestry.  Furthermore, I felt she was wrapping up certain story lines, relationships, and the way the story ended, ithe series could end at book #8 without any problems.  I am wondering where book #9 is going.

I really like this series but this book felt like a long intermission. Like the events between major plot points or setting up the next book. I begin to wonder when the series will end. I'm starting to think that Jem and Mandy will be adults and the "modern" setting of the book will go to the 21st century. The other thought is the series will go till either Clair and/or Jamie are dead.  This didn't end on a cliff hanger but I feel like there is more. Even the last pages, I felt like there should have been 2 more pages. I love the books but it's taking decades to read this. And I don't want to wait another 4 yrs for the next book.

This book was incredibly slow and hard to get thru until Part 6. The last third of the book was really good -- and almost made up for having to wade through the first and second thirds. The research done for the battles is impressive but the book read more like a textbook than an Outlander novel. As with the previous two books, nothing really happened until the last chapter or two. I loved all the historical details and tangents of the first four or five novels, but I can hardly force myself to read the last few books. Please PLEASE focus on the main story more and stop making us wade through 2/3 of a huge novel to get to the story!

Love this series of books! The characters are engaging and the attention to historical detail is stunning. Went through the entire series quickly, when  Starz' Outlander season concluded. As much as I enjoyed the adaptation, there is just so much more in the books! The relationship between Jamie and Claire is well done and the relationships between all the major characters are beautifully drawn. Halfway through the Lord John series now and simply don't know what I will do with myself when the books end. I'd recommend Patrick O'Brian's Aubrey/Maturin maritime series to anyone who enjoyed Gabaldon's brilliant books. Equally excellent.

I was lucky enough to be able to read the first seven Outlander books over the course of last summer, which helped to keep the many plot lines and characters straight. While Ms. Gabaldon's writing is superb, this book was hard to read. It had been too long since i finished the last one for me to remember where everyone was and why, and I'm still not sure why we had the bit with Roger's fathee, nor why Bree and family ended up on the Ridge after reuniting in 1739. The only thing I could imagine was that maybe the author is tired, and the series, though not answering all the questions it raised, COULD end now. The family is together

Like every single book in this series, I almost cried when it was over. I am desperately in love with every character. Diana Gabaldon absolutely nails it with this book, and based on the ending I have hope that there may be more to come.  If not, I have sure enjoyed the ride.  I didn't realize until I read her comments at the end that there are a lot of people who mistakenly believe that there are typos throughout the book, but I assure you, as one who just cannot tolerate that, there are not.  Because of the setting, words are sometimes used that are old and foreign, but properly spelled (or spelt, as some prefer). Amazing book.

It started out as a great story that I love, but there comes a time when it needs to come to an end.  I wanted more of Claire and Jamie, so I couldn't wait  to read the book  Left me a little disappointed because there were too many new characters  introduced too late in the series to care  about.  I  need to know how this story ends.  It should of ended at book 6.

All of the other books in the series I have finished in fewer than 2 days.  This took almost a week.  I didn't even want to read it.  (I have read the series over and over. I probably read Outlander 20 times.) I was unmoved by the characters that I once felt deeply for, and many things made me feel like she was going for the shock value.  It was  ok, but pale in comparison to her other work.  Mostly a disappointment.

I have loved all of the Outlander series and although I think the earlier books were better than the ones concentrating on the American War of Independence, Written in My Own Heart's Blood finished with the ending for which I had hoped. Diana Gabaldon's research for her books has been amazing, particularly into the Gaelic Language and the way she is able to re-introduce a character that you had almost forgotten, I found particularly clever. The rather repetitive love scenes were perhaps a bit much, but at the age of 87 it could be plain jealousy, anyway I enjoyed the series more than any others that I have read recently.
I am a huge fan of this series but this is by far the worst one.

I liked this book very much, but I didn't think it was quite as good as some of  the others in the series. I thought it moved a little slower than I would have liked and didn't have quite as much suspense and action ( although the segment with Brianna,Roger and the kids was intriguing to some degree; I wondered what the purpose was to have this bit in the story other than how it relates to the end of the book ). I am left wondering now if this is the final book in the series, or if it will continue.  I would definitely recommend reading this next installment though...how can you not if you have read all the others!

Although William is totally shattered by the revelation of his identity, he is still there to look out for Arabella-Jane and her sister, Fanny. Jamie and Claire follow the rebel army on its sweep through the north, and then leave Philadelphia after a tragic fire (taking the rest of the family with them) back to Fraser's Ridge. So of course, they land up in Savannah, Georgia...just as Roger and his ancestor, William Buccleigh MacKenzie, land up in 1739, to rescue Roger's father and send him back home to his own time. Brianna, Jem and Mandy flee the villains, first for the US and then, back to the past, to Roger...

I love this series and eagerly awaited this latest installment.  The author has a lovable set of characters with really interesting lives including the fact that they can time travel.  I also love the historical context and learn things I should have learned in high school.  The only complaint I have is there are huge gaps in Roger's and Brianna's experiences.  They are important characters.  I would have given this book 5 stars if the ending weren't so abrupt, which is a direct result of my criticism.  It's probable that the author is setting up the next book but this story could have been better developed.

Another good book in the series.  I always enjoy Gabaldon even when she is stuffing the story with filler stories to pad the size of the book.  I could see this main story continuing through another couple of books if the author and the readers keep their interest.  Several twists and turns occur that spark new interests.  Gabaldon can't help herself when she keeps adding a bit of Homosexual theme undercurrents at times.  I over look this for the content of the whole.  Readers in general will gain much more from reading the first book, Outlander, and continuing through the series.  If you have the stamina.
Boring, lots of words that went over past facts and barely introduced anything new.

I loved this series of books and was so excited when the new book came on the market, however, I thought some of the story lines were too long in the telling as though she was trying to write just for the sake of putting words down.The sex discriptions were over the top and although the love between Jamie and Clair and Roger and Brianna is very strong, I thought the long discriptions were over done.  I figured the family would be together at the end but it ends so abruptly and now have to wait possibly 4 years for the next one.

It's been so long since I've read the others in this series, so I had to get reacquainted with the characters.  But I enjoyed the continuing tale of Jamie and Claire during the late 1700's.  In this book we follow William, Jamie, Claire, and even Bree and Roger.  A large portion is about Bree and Roger, but just kind of leaves us hanging with them.  Lots of war camp scenes with Jamie and Claire, lots of blood and injuries for Claire to tend to.  Almost too much.  They meet George Washington and Benedict Arnold.  Overall, an entertaining book.  A little too much detail at times, but I still enjoyed it.

I enjoyed this series very much. While I loved parts of this last offering, I found the plot line very disjointed. There was just too much happening to too many separate characters. Gabaldon admits that she writes her novels in scenes and then "cements" them all together in the end. Unfortunately, in this volume the technique shows. It's a clunky novel, not a fluid one. I felt that Brianna and Roger's dilemma justified its own shorter book rather than being clumsily inserted into this one. Was it worth reading? Yes. And I do look forward to what happens to all these characters in the future.

Diana continues to amaze and entertain us with her Outlander series.  Not only does she provide wit, drama, and characters that you love; she enhances her books, and thereby her readers, through her extensive historical research and attention to era appropriate detail.  Unless you are a fan and a follower, it is difficult to explain how you become so immersed in the story that you are a part of it and you feel you know the characters intimately.  So proud that her series has now reached television production through the STARZ network as we all knew her stories were worthy to be shared in all venues.

I have read all of Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series and have enjoyed them all. For some reason this one was my least favorite. It just seemed to go every which way and I guess what I mean by that is that it really didn't delve into any one story line. There was so much going on and so many different names that it was hard to keep track of exactly what was happening. I guess I look at this book as "the loose end book" to get ready to put everything together for her next big one. At least I hope that's the plan.

I felt like I was being set up for the next book and, lo and behold, I was.  but I will buy the next book.  I have already read all of her other books at least twice.  I find them very interesting as far as the development of herbal medicines, possible ways things might have been invented, etc.  I just didn't find any of that in this book.  maybe I should have given it 3 stars, but I did like it.  i just kept reading, hoping that something would happen.  it's just that if you look at the book immediately before this one, it felt like this one ended where it should have begun, or very close to it.

If someone hasn't read all Gabaldon's previous books in the series, they are shortchanging themselves.  She gets classified in the library as a Romance section novelist but she is so much more than that.  You find yourself in another century, another culture, another world full of surprises, love of country, family and neighbors and experiencing the flavor of that culture because of her excellent storytelling ability.  There are many references to the prior novels but you won't appreciate the full picture until you read all her historical novels, full of depth and reality of living in that era.

Having read all of the books in this series I can say that I am satisfied with how this book wraps things up.  There are a few lose ends hanging at the end, but overall it was a great read and keeps us all in touch with the characters we have grown to know and love through the previous books.  I rated the plot as predictable based on the previous books in the series, but there are some exciting twists in the book that further deepen character development.  If you've read all of the other books, you need to read this one to have that sense of closure that comes with the ending of a series.

As always I love each and every one of Diana's outlander series book. Although after such a long wait for this one to come out I expected it to be a little more than it was. It seems like a good part of the. Novel was reminding those of us of previous events. Since it has been such a long time since the last novel many readers may have needed a refresher, but I would have hoped to be further into the story by the time I read the last page, causing some disappointment. I'm not sure by the ending if she intend on continuing the series or stopping, since the ending was fairly anticlimactic.
Exactly what was expected.  The time it took to get it was waaaaaaaaay too long.

I must say that I haven't finished the book.  I read the others in the series from beginning to end and this one I'm struggling with.  Is it because I've waited so long for the book to be published or might it be because  the book is so very long that I hesitate to get into it because there are so many other books to read? I don't know but I am slogging through it at a snails pace.  All the previous books I have loved and would recommend them. I wonder why they must be so long.  Seems like Ms. Gabaldon could make as much money if not more by having two or three books out of each one.

I  am a fan of the Outlander series but was extremely disappointed with this book.  It does not deliver a satisfactory ending.  Just before 9/11 Diana had started a book where Jamie had travelled two hundred years ahead (yes, he can time travel) and was on an airplane in full scotch regalia (no sword of course) and was headed toward England.  Diana evidently scrapped this after 9/11 and we had the TSA in real time.  It was unfortunate as I was glued to that chapter.  You will not like this book.  It feels as if she hurried to end it in time to start the television series on Starz.

Best writer on the planet!  This most recent installment of the series that all her fans hope never ends is all-consuming, passionate, funny, intelligent, heart-wrenching and heart-warming.  Reading this book is like visiting family again, that you haven't seen in a few years. You know these people, intimitely and thoroughly, and you want to catch up on all that has happened with them. At the end of the book, it's like it is time to go home again to your own real life, and you can't wait until the next visit...  Long live Jamie and Claire, Bree, Roger, the kids, Ian and Rachel!!
I love this series. Jamie is my Highlander dream! Can't wait for the next book!

NO SPOILERS HERE.  This book continues to charm us with the story of Jamie and Claire and their friends and family.  I love this saga as much as all the other fans out there.  I liked the ending of the book and look forward to book 9.  I read the first book in the series almost by accident a number of years ago.  I was on a road trip and had run out of things to read before the road ended.  I went into a gas station/store and bought the thickest book on the rack--Outlander .  I was hooked after the first few pages. I have enjoyed each of the rest of the books in the series.

I have loved this series since I read the first three a number of years ago. I'd basically forgotten about them until I stumbled over them again recently and found they're available for Kindle. I rather stupidly read this one - the 8th of the eight book Outlander series - before reading 4 thru 7, but it doesn't seem to matter all that much since things shift around in time anyway. Unlike most series I've tried to get back into after a long layoff, I found this again immediately engaging and it didn't really matter at all that I was unclear on who some of the personnel were!
Loved this book as much or more than all the others in the series. Great work,

Over the years I have read all of the "Outlander" series. I have enjoyed each book so much, not only because I fell in love with Jamie & Claire! Diana Gabaldon's writing is mesmerizing! Book 8 of the series was long awaited. The ending will flow into the next book & I hope Book 9 is in the making!! I am enjoying the TV series of the Outlander so much. Believe me when I say the actors that portray Jamie & Clare are almost exactly the way I envisioned they would look like!! By the way---I'm so glad Brianna & Roger w/children made it back to Fraser's Ridge!! CaroleB

I guess if that is all there is-----then that is it.  I was really disappointed in the ending.  I was of the opinion that this was the last book and I felt that it could have been more final, if that was the case.  Did she leave the possibility of writing another and including the reunion in it?  How did we make the years of difference when Roger and Bree moved back again?  It was confusing to me!  The story was good and I felt that made sense, but there were pieces that I felt were inconsistent  with the was that their lives had always been.  Maybe it was just my take.

Like many people, I heard of Outlander for the first time when the tv series came out last year. I've been zooming through the books ever since, trying to finish all the books before the series resumed (I made it through 7). I didn't enjoy it nearly as much as the earlier books. It was slow and plodding at times, some of the stories didn't seem to go anywhere or to add much value to the overall book. I also just didn't like some of the story lines, period. I read it without reading any reviews because now I'm hooked on the series, but it was an unimpressive showing.

I waited five years for this book to come out and was, honestly, disappointed.  So much of the emphasis in book 7 was on Roger and Bree and how to get Jemmy back through the stones, as well as on Fergus and his possible family history.  I was looking forward to how this would all play out in WIMOHB (aka MOBY).  Instead of truly following those story lines, they were given an almost cursory summation while most of the book concentrated on William trying to come to terms with his true parentage.  Would have liked to have seen less moping and more story development.

So good to catch up with my good friends, Jamie and Claire. As I often tell people when I describe these books, the character development is so good that I have caught myself wondering how my friends Claire and Jamie are doing, as if they were close friends who live far away rather than fictional characters. Likewise, the settings are so beautifully brought to life that I actually felt after reading Outlander for the first time that I had experienced life in the 1740's, sleeping in the heather or living in a castle with only a peat fire to warm the stone room.

I've read all the other Highlander books and also some of the John Gray books as well.  On many of these, I absolutely "lived" for these books, putting practically everything else on hold so that I could continue reading them.  But I enjoyed this one, too.  By this time, I have come to feel so comfortable with Claire, Jamie and all the other characters that I almost consider them friends, and I enjoy finding out what happens to them.  So, I'll continue to buy and read Diana Gabaldon's books.  She is a very good story teller, and I like good stories.

I highly recommend this and the whole series of Outlander. For readers who enjoy a book with the combination of love, action, and solid history, Gabaldon is master of her craft. You become a participant in the story and wish it were your own. The people in her novels are so developed, so likeable, they become part of your family. I couldn't put the series down for part of the day that was strictly devoted to them. And I look forward to seeing more of Starz' tv production of the story. Lucky for me it's almost January when it starts up again. A masterpiece!

As with all the other Outlander books, I was swept up and carried along on an epic adventure with old and new friends. The characters so familiar to me now that it is hard to quit reading throughout the book for want to know what will happen to them next. And yet as I get close to the ending I want to slow down and stretch it out for I know I will miss them so when done. The ending was perfect but has me already longing for the next book....which is precisely why I am now going to start back at Outlander and read them all again! Well done Diana, well done!

This is the best series of books I have ever read.  They are historical, fantasy, love stories - with humor.  The characters are heart warming, aggravating, lovable, despicable, caring, smart, dumb --- totally believable.  It is difficult for me to separate the series of books to comment on just one.  This one answered many questions and left me with many - looking forward to the next.  Ms. Gabaldon is an exceptional writer - I hope she continues to write for as long as possible.  I thank her for the Outlander series and the characters I have come to love.

This one was the most disjointed of all the books in the series.  It followed people and events I didn't care about while leaving many people and things not completed at the end of the book.  I would rather not hear about meeting and dealing with the rapist, but read more about the kids returning.  Just when it was getting to the good part and I wanted to hear more the book ended.  Not fair!  It felt like the author got tired of her characters and just decided to let it end.

Being a fan of the Outlander series, I very much enjoyed the long-awaited and highly anticipated Book 8.  I would have preferred a much shorter military section and more details about events in the last third of the book which almost seemed summarized - especially after the laborious and lengthy military action. It was difficult to keep the different factions of the war straight and really had very little bearing on the story as a whole. This reader is hopeful that Book 9 will be written and in distribution in a much shorter timeframe than was Book 8!!

I have thoroughly enjoyed all of Galbadon's previous books in the Outlander series an was excitedly waiting for this one to come out.  However, I was somewhat disappointed in this one.  Maybe she has written too much about them and is having a hard time coming up with fresh ideas for this family.  It is slow, plodding and skips around too much among the different characters and scenarios. It was stuck in the American Revolution for the entire book with few short exceptions.  If there is another one, I hope it will rival her first seven in this series.
Lots of filler and some lose threads.  Not a great finale to a great story!

I have slowed down my reading so that I can enjoy this book for a longer period of time. I am always very pleased with the author's level of research, since the time periods that she is writing about happen to have been an area of study for me and it bothers me when I find inaccuracies in literature. Her ability of making the reader care about the characters continues in this, the eighth book in the series. She still has some surprises up her sleeve, which also adds to the reader's enjoyment.  I do recommend this book, and the whole Outlander series.

I have said before that these books are long and it appears that the author is being paid by the word.  Having said that; these books are clearly and accurately written when it comes to the events of the history of Scotland, England, France and the Carolinas.  The author places her characters in the middle of the war and they fight along side of our heroes like Washington.  All I can say is keep reading because the books are worth the time it takes to read them.  I love history, and the idea that the stone circles around the world do have a purpose.

Continues where the last book ended. Lots of action and adventure, history and romance. Oh and time travel. Once again there is the cliff hanger so I can't wait for the next book. Lol I have read the novella, "A leaf on the Wind of All Hallows." waiting for this book and it does add a bit of information that will help tie the books together. I have enjoyed all the Outlander books, and the tv series is doing a great job of following the first book. Guess, while I'm waiting for the next book I'll have to check out the Lord John books as well. Cheers

thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. Read the first book over 15 years ago and stopped reading part wat through the fiery cross. Don't rememer why I stopped. Started the entire series again in October and just didn't want to stop this time. I agree with many reviews that parts get a bit tedious when storyline just goes on and on about the revolutionary war or in-depth descriptions of Claire's surgeries. Just keep to Jamie & Claire and family. I thought this was the last book, pleasantly surprised to know there will be more. Hate waiting 4-5 years

Loved every single word!  The book just makes me anticipate the next one.  The whole story of Claire Beauchamp and Jamie Frazier is enthralling.  Whether the whole "time travel" idea is possible is questionable, but I'd sure like to try it to see history up close and in person.  The details and research Gabaldon uses make all her books so believable, it is just like stepping back in time.  They also make the reader question the "wonderful" comforts of today against the simple pleasures and friend and family based life of the past.

I am about half way through this book!  I have been trying to make it last!  I just love Diana Gabaldon!  Can't wait to get my hands on her books!  All this started with a paperback book I happened to find in a box of used books.  I love time travel books, but hers have so much more depth in the story lines.  She can't write them fast enough for me!  I hope she continues with Jamie and Claire and their family!  These books just keep getting better and better.  Thank you, Diana for writting them!  Thank you Amazon for making them available to me!

I am not sure if this is the last of the series and maybe that is why I am a little disappointed and a lot sad. I waited a long time for this book and really wanted to here more of Claire and Jamie, Jenny and the children, and what happened after Bree and the children went through the stones. What happened to Roger? Did they go back to the Ridge? Did Jenny go with them or stay with Ian? So many things...Please Diana, don't stop writing about them. I am watching the series on TV and am very happy you have made them stay true to the story line.

I love the Outlander series and I waited years for this book to come out.  But to be honest, I as quite disappointed.  I slogged my way through this book - getting bogged down for most of the book in the Revolution.  Too much of Hal, John and William (along with numerous superfluous characters) and not enough of Jamie and Clair.  Bree and Roger are inserted briefly at one point, never to be seen again until the final chapter.  Too much detail and too little story.

Diana Gabaldon out did herself again. I have looked forward to this book coming out for a long time and it didn't disappoint. Although the main premise is still centered around Claire and Jamie there is a lot of interaction from all the other members of the family - from Ian to Briana and Roger - and of course we can't forget John Grey and William. Oh and the ending! It was wrapped up in true Outlander fashion with a few loose ends being wrapped up and yet leaving you wanting more. One more in a great series of books that you can't put down.

OK, I admit it--I am addicted to Diana Gabaldon.  I don't know how she does it, but she continues to make me wait in breathless anticipation for her next offering in the "Outlander" series.  I think this is a series one will either love or hate, and I am definitely a lover.  I owned all the hardback books, but when I got my Kindle, I loaded all of them on the Kindle and then sat down and read them as one huge book (I did take meal and sleep breaks).  Diana Gabaldon is a brilliant, imaginative woman who has written a wonderful story.

The authors beautiful command of words and descriptive phrases is here. Her research is evident, as always. The story, however, turned around a few times and laid down to sleep.  If I had not read the previous 7 books, the constant references to what went before would have been murky at best. Since I did read the previous books, I did not need or appreciate the focus on looking back instead of moving forward. I'm still holding onto hope for better in the future.

I would definitely give this book 5 stars.  Absolutely love this series, Have read all 8 in this series , as well as a few extra, .  I'm always disappointed when I'm finished , but look forward to reading the next one.  I only hope the follow-up to this one comes out fairly soon, while the characters are still fresh in my mind.  It's nice to include the other characters, but I do enjoy hearing about Jamie ad Clare and their adventures.  Looking forward to see what happens now with Brianna and her family as they join Jamie and Clare again.

I'm an Outlander fan, but this is not my favorite book in the series.  I can't exactly pinpoint why, but it didn't grab me like all of the others did.  It suddenly felt repetitive... or like I was being strung along without being given the goods.  I still think Diana Gabaldon is an astounding writer, I guess I just got spoiled by the incredible satisfaction I got from all of the other books in this series, including the Lord John novels.  This is my second least favorite, behind... was it book 4 that took place primarily over a few days?
I have read the entire Jamie & Claire series, this last book was Insipid!

So disappointed in this book. After waiting such a long time for it to come out, I've been very dismayed at how it plods along just rehashing original and well used story lines. It seems to be rather chaotic, jumping about with the characters and their issues. Nothing is cohesive. I have read 4 books in between trying to plow through this one. I have read all the other "Outlander" books, three times. I loved each one immensely. This one...no so much.

although l have not completed reading all of it as yet, the only reason being that l was away for more than a month and was just to worn out from each days activities to open it, upon re-opening it again l find it hard to close each time..l keep telling myself, just one more chapter then l will bookmark it, but no, l just cant help myself and have to start the next one until finally l am reading the pages through my closed eyelids..chuckles..it is worth the 5 stars..Diana, you have done it again...cant wait to see the series on telly..

I have been hooked on this series ever since I read the first one, haven't quite finished yet, but I'm kind of reading slowly because I don't want it to end.  These books are historical fiction at its best and most entertaining.  The characters come alive and become your friends.  Good sex, humorous, well written,with that extra quirk of traveling in time.  One of my favorite authors and my favorite series ever.  Not sure I want to watch the miniseries, because the actors can't possibly be better than I way I envision them in my mind.

It really is an OK book.  Honestly, for the 5 year wait, I was hoping for more excitement, especially considering the cliff hanger of the last book.  I am a bit of an artist myself, so I understand you can't force the muse.  But I just felt like there are parts that could have been explored more, and others less, to really round it out.  I felt similarly to the end of Wheel of Time.  I just don't feel like I want to re-read this one, as I did with other of the Outlander books.  Of course I'll read the next one, and anxiously await it.

Waited for soooooo long for a new Outlander book!!  Tore through this one so I could catch up on all my favorite characters. Diana has done a wonderful job of keeping the story line going (don't know how she does it!) My only small complaint is that she has created so many wonderful characters and plot lines that the book continually "jumps" (sorry for the pun) from one to the next and it can take a paragraph or so when starting each chapter to figure out whose voice the reader is hearing. Still can't wait for the next one!!

Obviously Diana is an awesome writer, but this isn't her best. Her stories weren't as saturated as in other books. The story continues as consistently, but without the breathless page turning as before. She skipped ahead much of the story, it feels like just to avoid having to write it (roger and Bree sowing up on the ridge). Not her usual style. Disappointed to say the least. Hopefully the next will be better. I'm shocked this book took so long to write.

I have been waiting for two long years for this book to come out so I could get the answers to all the story threads Gabaldon left hanging.  However, I feel like she left as many story threads unanswered this time as she did last time.  I'm not sure I'm up to waiting another 2-3 years for another book (assuming she intends to write one!)  For example, what will ever happen with Fergus?  With William?  Is  Ben going to stay lost forever?  It makes me mad.

The last 200 pages tie everything together.  If you are finding it to be a slow start, keep reading!  I'm a die hard Gabaldon fan.  This is by far, my all time favorite series.  I liked this book better than the last one, and if there are any negatives, I'd have to say that it would be any war scenes that are not related to William.  I find the war scenes tedious.  However, apart from those,this book furthers the characters story lines.  The ending is wonderful and sets the continuation of the story up in an exciting cliff hanger!

I kept reading for plot, but it just is not the same anymore. Not as much humor and fire in her writing. The story lines were not truly interwoven; it seemed like she wrote the five or seven different subplots separately and some editor chopped them up and shuffled them around. Jamie and Claire are like old friends of mine now, and to tell you the truth it's a bit awkward their having sex in the woods all the time. Wonderful series, time to say goodbye.

After giving up on the series years ago after Book 6, which I felt included too much tedious detail and just in general didn't grab me, I came back to it a month or so ago (watching some of the Starz TV series made me curious as to what had happened with the books).  Maybe it's because I was able to read both books in quick succession, but Book 7 and this book have really gotten me invested in the characters again and now I am eagerly awaiting the next book in the series (though I'm guessing I may be waiting for quite some time).

After waiting 5 years I had hoped for more than this.  Gave up before the war - skipped to where Bree is trying to explain how to 'travel' and don't know if I'll finish it.  Just so disappointed that these vibrant characters have been let down in this book.  So many characters of no consequence, so much padding...yada yada...I'm off to the library and very glad I did not buy this book.

I have seen the first episode of Outlander on Starz back in August 2014. Never heard of the series before... but after the first episode, I was so intrigued to see what happens after they reached the castle, a week being toooo long.  This is when I found out there are books.... and not one.... but eight.  The same day I went and bought my first book.  In November 2014 I have finished reading all 8 books.  Loved the series.  Loved the 8th book, and cannot wait to see what happens in the 9th.  I hope it will be a 10th one as well.

I have enjoyed every book of the "Outlander" series and always regret when I finish a book. Each one brings new surprises and even more character development, especially in the dynamic of Jamie and Claire.  Theirs is truly a love story for all time.  The story is epic and I love the detail of each period, weaving real-life characters with fiction. Diana Gabaldon is a unique writer and storyteller, who brings great talent to the world of historical fiction...a world I have inhabited for many years in my leisure time.

Another fantastic story of Claire and Jamie Fraser and their family's saga as part of the Outlander series.  It was hard to put the book down and harder to come to the end.  Diana Gabaldon weaves the historical aspects so wonderfully throughout the story and fits the science fiction in in such a way that makes it seem as normal activity.  The very personal lives of the characters and their experiences become so real as you read their stories.  Highly recommend the series, including "Written in My Own Heart's Blood".

After having read all the previous books by Gabaldon, I greatly anticipated the new book.  It included so many characters and seemed at times to wander aimlessly from one set of characters to the other that I actually found it boring at times.  For instance, the lengthy description of Roger's search in Scotland.  Some of the relationships between different characters seemed contrived.  Not up to the quality of the previous books in my opinion.

Jamie and Claire are older now - the passion not as intense, the adventures not QUITE as turbulent as in their youth, but still their love and the love of family and friends is stronger than ever.  Drama and excitement are ever-present but through it all Claire, Jamie, Brianna, Roger and all those other characters we have come to know and love so well continue to move us breathlessly through the 18th century.  Just as good as all the others but perhaps a little poignant as time moves toward the inevitable.  I loved it.

As always, Diana Gabaldon delivers.  This book is rich with history, magnificent details, stirring romance and war torn tension and betrayal.  Ms. Gabaldon has done a wonderful job of aging these characters, adding the wisdom and clarity that comes with age and experience.  As with all of the Outlander novels, the scenes are so clearly written that you feel as if you are in the room with Claire as she performs her surgery, or on the battlefield with Jamie...the book is provocative and riveting.  Hope it's not the last!

Once again an outstanding book.  I love when you can feel like the characters in a book are people you know.  After 8 books in this series, I can say these characters are my alternate family.  The ups and downs and in and outs of their lives are all skilfully woven into a totally enjoyable package.  Even though there are stories yet to be told, The ending of this installment was one I can live with for awhile.. . . . . but I still want more

The long awaited installment doesnot disappoint.  The central part of the book revolves around the battle of Monmouth, NJ, a real life battle at which George Washington became so discussed by the conduct of General Charles Lee that he summarily dismissed him from the army.  In the meantime , Roger, believing that Jem has been sent back in time by Cameron, has gone back himself and finds himself in a considerably earlier time than before. Devotees of this saga will be in suspense through this book.  Don't miss it!

Snooze fest, honestly, half way through.  She should have stopped at book 6.  7 and 8 have left much to be desired and lost much of the magic of the series.  Book 6 left you feeling really wanting to know what happened to everyone after the Ridge...but the wait hasn't really been worth it, in my opinion  What's the point of writing 1,000 pages of minutia but no really good story?  Not quite sure what is going on in the author's mind.

I just finished the 8th book in the Outlander series and am going to read it again, immediately! I LOVE you the detail and accuracy Diana writes with, her books  so meaty, they keep you coming back for more! Claire is so believable and Jamie, well he's every woman's dream but much more than that. His character is flawed and human, endearing and exasperating, but strong and loyal to those he loves. I have read the other 7 books at least 20 times, I am not exaggerating. I can't wait for book 9 and hopefully 10!
Not as riveting as some previous installments, it drags on in places.

The attention to historical detail is astounding.  I just started to re-read Outlander because I started to miss Jamie and Claire when I finished this latest Outlander book.  I know my review should be more about the story line of "Written in My Own Hearts Blood" but frankly I don't really care what the story is about.  It could be 800 pages of the characters reading the newspaper and I would still think it was an awesome book.  I feel like I know them and as long as Jamie is on the page I'm good :)

Love her Outlander series, but this one ended with almost all the loose ends tied up. My first thought was this is the last one when I finished it, but then when I thought about it, I realized there were a few things left unresolved. History is one of my passions, but delivered in a historical/fantasy context is the best way to read it. She does an amazing job with historical events, but it is too long between books so I have trouble picking up some of the story lines without going back to the earlier ones.

A wonderful, if long, read, and no telling if it's the last one. (I said that in my head like Sean Connery). I simply loved everything about it. More so perhaps because I'm now watching the series on Starz,  up to Episode 6, and it is marvelously ON BOOK!! My husband has not read the books and is always asking me things like, "Does Jamie ever get to kill him?". Yes, I do answer him. If there is a next one (this one sorta had a sense of finality about it), I will gobble it right up too. Read them all, guys.

I am a huge fan of this series and have reread most of the previous books twice. This one probably won't get a reread as I didn't think there were enough significant events that happened. I also think it focused so much on details of the historical figures that I got kind of lost at times and was somewhat predictable. That said, it still had my attention and was enjoyable - just not one of those "can't put it down" novels. I am looking forward to the next book as I like where the story went in the end.

I did not enjoy this book as much as the other books in the series. I think the reason is that there was not enough about Jamie and Claire and their story. Jamie and Claire (and John Grey) are the strong, likable characters in the series and it is their stories I am interested in. Bree and her husband are just not that appealing or interesting. Bree always seems sort of aloof and self-centered. William is spoiled and whiny and Ian has a scary side to him. Looking forward to more about Jamie and Claire!

Diana has done it again! I really enjoyed this new instillation in this wonderful series. I did not enjoy so much detail and significant amount of the story involved in the war scenes.
